{"uri": "8231374519", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "08:35:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T08:35:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T08:35:16Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.9019607901573181, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3021171-vietnams-president-to-lam-steps-in-as-communist-party-chief-amid-health-concerns-for-nguyen-phu-trong", "title": "Vietnam's President To Lam Steps in as Communist Party Chief Amid Health Concerns for Nguyen Phu Trong | Politics", "body": "Vietnam's President To Lam has taken over the responsibilities of Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong, who is currently focusing on an unspecified health treatment, the party announced on Thursday. The move follows months of speculation regarding Trong's weakening health. The party has not disclosed specifics about his treatment.\n\nLam, a former head of internal security, is seen as a top candidate to succeed Trong when his term concludes in 2026. The powerful Politburo has assigned Lam to oversee the Party Central Committee, the Politburo, and the Secretariat, according to a statement from the party's central office. In Vietnam's Communist-ruled system, the party chief holds the most influential position, despite the country having no official paramount ruler. Trong, 80, has been in office since 2011.\n\nSince 2017, Trong, a Marxist-Leninist ideologue, has initiated a China-style anti-corruption campaign known as the 'blazing furnace.' However, he has been visibly fragile in recent months and has missed several high-level meetings. In a surprising gesture, the Politburo awarded Trong with the Gold Star medal, Vietnam's highest honor for public officials, on Thursday.\n\nLam was elected president in May following the resignation of several top leaders amid unspecified allegations of wrongdoing, part of Trong's extensive anti-graft campaign. Lam, a central figure in this crackdown, vowed to continue the fight against corruption after his election. Vietnam's main stock market rose by 0.5% following the announcement. A senior Western diplomat based in Hanoi commented on Lam's expanded authority, saying it could be good for stability but noted that its impact on economic, foreign, and domestic policies remains to to \"focus\" on his health, the party said on Thursday.\n\nPresident To Lam would take over as the country's caretaker leader, the party said in an online statement.\n\nThe party said Lam had been assigned to lead the works of the party central committee, the politburo, the secretariat, while Trong would \"focus on active treatment\".\n\nLed by the Communist Party general secretary, Vietnam's leadership structure gives the president the second-most authority -- but the position is largely seen as ceremonial.\n\nThe communist government's four-person hierarchy also includes the prime minister and the head of the National Assembly.\n\nTrong's ailing health has fuelled widespread speculation that he will not be able to stay in power until the 2026 party congress that is expected to appoint a successor.\n\nMore from this section Residents with flooded basements take stock of the damage after severe storm Anti-Trump protesters march outside Republican National Convention in Milwaukee Woman jumps out of window in Franklin Township to avoid being struck by bullets\n\nIn office since 2011, the party leader has enjoyed remarkable longevity in his role, which rights groups say has coincided with Vietnam's drift toward authoritarianism.\n\nLam, 67, served as Vietnam's public security minister before being voted in as president by Vietnam's rubber-stamp parliament after a major anti-corruption campaign forced his predecessor to resign.\n\nThousands of people -- including several senior government and business leaders -- have been caught up in the Southeast Asian country's crackdown on graft, led by Trong.\n\nAnalysts have said that Lam, who is deputy head of the steering committee on anti-corruption, has weaponised its investigations to take down his "sim": 0.8549019694328308, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/07/19/world/asia-oceania/vietnamese-leader-takes-health-break/1958338", "title": "Vietnamese leader takes health break", "body": "HANOI -- Vietnam's 80-year-old leader and Communist Party General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong will take a break to \"focus\" on his health, the party said on Thursday.\n\nPresident To Lam would take over as the country's caretaker leader, the party said in an online statement.\n\nLam has been assigned to lead the works of the party central committee, the politburo, the secretariat, while Trong would \"focus on active treatment,\" it added.\n\nLed by the Communist Party general secretary, Vietnam's leadership structure gives the president the second-most authority, but the position is largely seen as ceremonial.\n\nThe communist government's four-person hierarchy also includes the prime minister and the head of the National Assembly.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nTrong's ailing health has fueled widespread speculation that he will not be able to stay in power until the 2026 party congress that is expected to appoint a successor.\n\nIn office since 2011, Trong has enjoyed remarkable longevity in his role, which rights groups say has coincided with Vietnam's drift toward authoritarianism.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nLam, 67, served as Vietnam's public security minister before being voted in as president by Vietnam's rubber-stamp parliament after a major anti-corruption campaign forced his predecessor to resign.\n\nThousands of people -- including several senior government and business leaders -- have been caught up in the Southeast Asian country's crackdown on graft, led by Trong.\n\nAnalysts have said Lam, who is deputy head of the steering committee on anti-corruption, has weaponized its investigations to take down his political rivals.\n\nIn his first remarks as president, Lam said he was \"determined to fight corruption and negative phenomena.\"", "source": {"uri": Thursday.\n\nPresident To Lam would take over as the country's caretaker leader, the party said in an online statement.\n\nThe party said Lam had been assigned to lead the works of the party central committee, the politburo, the secretariat, while Trong would \"focus on active treatment\".\n\nLed by the Communist Party general secretary, Vietnam's leadership structure gives the president the second-most authority -- but the position is largely seen as ceremonial.\n\nThe communist government's four-person hierarchy also includes the prime minister and the head of the National Assembly.\n\nTrong's ailing health has fuelled widespread speculation that he will not be able to stay in power until the 2026 party congress that is expected to appoint a successor.\n\nIn office since 2011, the party leader has enjoyed remarkable longevity in his role, which rights groups say has coincided with Vietnam's drift toward authoritarianism.\n\nLam, 67, served as Vietnam's public security minister before being voted in as president by Vietnam's rubber-stamp parliament after a major anti-corruption campaign forced his predecessor to resign.\n\nThousands of people -- including several senior government and business leaders -- have been caught up in the Southeast Asian country's crackdown on graft, led by Trong.\n\nAnalysts have said that Lam, who is deputy head of the steering committee on anti-corruption, has weaponised its investigations to take down his political rivals.\n\nIn his first remarks as president, Lam said he was \"determined to fight corruption and {"uri": "2024-07-425871658", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "10:55:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T10:55:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T09:40:01Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.843137264251709, "url": "https://www.ccenterdispatch.com/news/national/article_16b7d0f6-ceed-5c5a-b96d-459473b4887a.html", "title": "Vietnam president handed power as party leader seeks medical care", "body": "Vietnam's communist regime handed the reins of power Thursday to the country's largely ceremonial president, as 80-year-old leader and party General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong temporarily stood down for health reasons.\n\nThe politburo appointed President To Lam to take over as both the party and country's caretaker leader, the party said in an online statement.\n\nLam was assigned to lead the works of the party central committee, the politburo and the secretariat, while Trong would \"focus on active treatment\".\n\n\"The Politburo calls on the entire party, people and army to have absolute trust in the party's leadership and state management,\" the statement said.\n\nIt gave no indication of how long Lam would be assigned to the role, nor did it address why Trong required medical treatment.\n\nThe country's communist regime, which is in the midst of a complete overhaul, has undergone a series of upheavals in recent months, with two presidents, ministers and business leaders falling from grace as part of a vast anti-corruption operation.\n\nHeaded by the Communist Party general secretary, Vietnam's leadership structure gives the president the second-most authority -- but the position is largely seen as ceremonial.\n\nThe communist government's hierarchy also includes the prime minister and the head of the National Assembly.\n\nTrong's poor health has fuelled widespread speculation that he will not be able to stay in power until the 2026 party congress that is expected to appoint a successor.\n\nIn office since 2011, the party leader has enjoyed remarkable longevity in his role, which rights groups say has coincided with increasing authoritarianism.\n\nKnown for being a technocrat and on good terms with Beijing, Trong had structured the party around himself, benefiting from a decade of economic growth that has strengthened his legitimacy.\n\nLam, 67, served as Vietnam's public security minister before being voted in as president in May by Vietnam's rubber-stamp parliament after his predecessor was forced to resign in a major anti-corruption campaign.\n\nAnalysts said at the time that Lam, who was deputy head of the steering committee on anti-corruption matters, had weaponised investigations to take down his political rivals.\n\nIn his first remarks as president, Lam said he was {"uri": "8234041784", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "19:18:42", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T19:18:42Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T19:16:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8352941274642944, "url": "https://thediplomat.com/2024/07/vietnam-communist-party-chief-nguyen-phu-trong-dies-at-age-80/", "title": "Vietnam Communist Party Chief Nguyen Phu Trong Dies at Age 80", "body": "Trong had dominated Vietnamese politics since 2011. Now attention turns to his successor, former security minister To Lam.\n\nNguyen Phu Trong, general secretary of Vietnam's ruling Communist Party and the country's most powerful politician, has died following months of ill health, official media said Friday. He was 80.\n\n\"General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Party Nguyen Phu Trong passed away at 13:38 on July 19, 2024, at the 108 Central Military Hospital due to old age and serious illness,\" the Nhan Dan newspaper said.\n\nOfficial media said a state funeral would be held.\n\nTrong had dominated Vietnamese politics since 2011, when he was elected party chief. During his tenure, he worked to consolidate the Communist Party's power in Vietnam's single-party political system. In the decade before he took the top role in Vietnamese politics, the balance of power had shifted more toward the governmental wing led by then-Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung.\n\nBorn in 1944 in Hanoi, Trong was a Marxist-Leninist ideologue who earned a degree in philosophy before becoming a member of the Communist Party at the age of 22. He viewed corruption as the single gravest threat in maintaining the party's legitimacy.\n\n\"A country without discipline would be chaotic and unstable,\" Trong said in 2016 after being reelected to the party's helm. Officially, Vietnam has no top leader, but the Communist Party chief is traditionally seen as the most powerful.\n\nTrong launched a sweeping anti-corruption campaign known as the \"blazing furnace\" that singed both business and political elites. Since 2016, thousands of party officials have been disciplined. They included former presidents Nguyen Xuan Phuc and Vo Van Thuong and the former head of parliament, Vuong Dinh Hue. In all, eight members of the powerful Politburo were ousted on corruption allegations, compared to none between 1986 and 2016.\n\nTrong studied in the Soviet Union from 1981 to 1983, and there was speculation that under his leadership, Vietnam would move closer to Russia and China. However, the Southeast Asian nation followed a pragmatic policy of \"bamboo diplomacy,\" a phrase he coined that referred to the plant's flexibility, bending but not breaking in the shifting headwinds of geopolitics.\n\nVietnam maintained its traditional ties with its much larger neighbor, China, dispute differences over sovereignty in the South China Sea. But it also drew closer to the United States, elevating its ties with its former Vietnam War foe to its highest diplomatic status, a comprehensive strategic partnership.\n\nAs a result, Trong achieved the rare feat of hosting the top leaders of the United States, China, and Russia in less than a year between September 2023 and June 2024. His adroit balancing of the fierce geopolitical rivals was displayed in the outpouring of condolences upon his passing.\n\nThe Central Committee of the Chinese Communist Party sent its condolences to its Vietnamese counterpart and \"deeply mourned\" Trong's death, the state-run Xinhua news agency reported Friday.\n\nThe White House also issued a statement of condolences, with President Joe Biden calling Trong \"a champion of the deep ties between the American and Vietnamese people whose leadership helped nurture the friendship and partnership our countries enjoy today.\"\n\nLikewise, Russia's President Vladimir Putin said Trong had \"earned enormous respect among his fellow country people and a remarkable reputation in the international arena.\" In a telegram sent to Lam, and posted on the Kremlin's website, Putin said, \"In Russia, he [Trong] will always be remembered as a true friend of our country, who made a huge personal contribution to the establishment and development of a comprehensive strategic partnership between Moscow and Hanoi.\"\n\nTrong's legacy is mixed, with the unintended consequence of the anti-graft campaign being an erosion of institutions within the Communist Party, said Nguyen Khac Giang, a visiting fellow in the Vietnam Studies Program at Singapore's ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute. The party institutions were the bedrock ensuring that a balance of power remained among its different factions, he said.\n\n\"Vietnam has become more and more like China, where institutions and norms don't really matter as much as personal power,\" Giang said.\n\nVietnamese President To Lam was appointed the party caretaker on July 18, with the official announcement saying Trong was receiving treatment for his ill health. As Vietnam's top security official, Lam had led the anti-graft campaign until becoming president in May, when his predecessor resigned after being caught up in corruption allegations.\n\nThe party's Politburo asked Lam to \"preside over the work of the Party Central Committee, the Politburo, and the Secretariat,\" according to a statement from its central office, which was the first official confirmation of Trong's poor health.\n\nRumors about his health have swirled in Vietnamese politics since he was first hospitalized in 2019, and more recently when he appeared extremely frail while meeting visiting Russian President Vladmir Putin.\n\nTrong's death leaves behind a yawning political vacuum in Vietnam. Although Lam is widely viewed as the likely next party chief, Giang predicted \"a very uncertain time\" in Vietnamese politics because the norms and institutions governing the country are \"very shaky.\"\n\n\"Now it isn't only about the rules or norms, but it is also about who holds the most power,\" Giang said.\n\nIn early 2026, Vietnam's Communist Party will hold a national congress that will determine who holds the top-most leadership positions for the next five years.", "source": {"uri": "thediplomat.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Diplomat Magazine"}, "authors": [], {"uri": "8231539379", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "10:11:34", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T10:11:34Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T10:10:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8313725590705872, "url": "https://www.tbsnews.net/worldbiz/asia/vietnams-president-lam-takes-party-chief-duties-trong-focuses-health-902071", "title": "Vietnam's President Lam takes party chief duties as Trong focuses on", "body": "Vietnam's President To Lam has taken over the duties of Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong who is focusing on an unspecified health treatment, the party said on Thursday.\n\nThe extraordinary move comes after months of speculation that Trong's health was weakening. The party did not clarify what treatment he is receiving and a spokesperson for the ministry of foreign affairs had no additional information to share when asked at a regular media briefing.\n\nLam, a former head of internal security, has been widely seen as a top candidate to replace Trong when his term ends in 2026. The party's powerful Politburo has tasked him with temporarily presiding over \"the work of the Party Central Committee, the Politburo and the Secretariat,\" according to a statement from the party's central office.\n\n\"Looking at the current state, Lam has the highest chance to become the acting party chief until 2026,\" said Nguyen Khac Giang, expert on Vietnam at Singapore-based think tank ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute.\n\nFor Lam to be officially appointed as acting party chief, a new Politburo decision will be needed.\n\nIn its statement on Thursday, the Politburo called on the party, the army and the people \"to have absolute confidence in the leadership of the party\".\n\nThough Vietnam officially has no paramount ruler, the party chief holds the most powerful position in the Communist-ruled nation. Trong, 80, has been in the post since 2011.\n\nCORRUPTION CRACKDOWN\n\nTrong, a Marxist-Leninist ideologue, has since 2017 unleashed what many see as a China-style crackdown on corruption known as \"blazing furnace\". But in recent months, he has appeared fragile in public events and missed several top-level meetings.\n\nIn a surprise move, the Politburo awarded Trong on Thursday the Gold Star medal, the country's highest honour for public officials.\n\nLam was elected president in May after several top leaders quit amid accusations of unspecified wrongdoing.\n\nLam, a key player in the crackdown, promised after his election to \"resolutely and persistently continue the fight against corruption\", despite its negative impact on public investment.\n\n\"Whoever takes over from Trong to become the next party chief, it is essential to keep his anti-corruption campaign legacy to have the authority in front of other political elites, keep the system's stability and gain favour from others,\" said Giang.\n\nVietnam's main stock market edged up 0.5% after the announcement.\n\nA Hanoi-based senior Western diplomat said he saw Lam's expanded powers as good for stability.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8233596848", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "13:34:36", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T13:34:36Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T13:34:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8274509906768799, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3023133-vietnams-leadership-transition-the-death-of-nguyen-phu-trong", "title": "Vietnam's Leadership Transition: The Death of Nguyen Phu Trong | Politics", "body": "Nguyen Phu Trong, Vietnam's Communist Party chief, died at 80. Trong, who held power for 13 years, led significant economic growth and an anti-corruption crackdown. His duties are temporarily assigned to President To Lam, with potential consolidation of power under Lam, posing both opportunities and risks for Vietnam.\n\nNguyen Phu Trong, the ruling Communist Party chief of Vietnam, passed away on Friday at the age of 80. Holding the country's most powerful position for 13 years, Trong oversaw rapid economic growth, a prolonged anti-corruption campaign, and a pragmatic foreign policy. President To Lam has been assigned his duties temporarily, with the potential to consolidate powers if he retains the roles.\n\nThe Party announced that Trong died in the early afternoon due to old age and illness, without providing further details. His medical team noted that he received comprehensive treatment from top medical experts and the state.\n\nWhile Lam assumed Trong's duties last Thursday as the party chief's health declined, a decision is yet to be made on whether Lam will formally take over until the current term ends in 2026 or if a new leader will be elected from within the party ranks. {"uri": "2024-07-425989325", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "12:36:56", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T12:36:56Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T11:15:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8235294222831726, "url": "https://www.ccenterdispatch.com/news/national/article_5d686b2a-9222-54ee-98e0-604051b3eda8.html", "title": "Vietnam president handed power as party leader seeks medical care", "body": "President To Lam is taking Vietnam's reins temporarily while its current leader receives medical treatment\n\nVietnam's communist party handed the reins of power Thursday to the country's largely ceremonial president, To Lam, as its 80-year-old leader and general secretary temporarily stood down for health reasons.\n\nThe politburo appointed Lam, 67, to take over as both the party and country's caretaker leader while current General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong focused \"on active treatment\", the Vietnamese Communist Party said in an online statement.\n\nThe party gave no indication of how long Lam would be assigned to the role, nor did it address why Trong required medical treatment.\n\nBut one analyst suggested the rare announcement on the sensitive issue signalled the arrival of a new leader who could remain in power for years to come, calling it a \"total victory\" for Lam.\n\nLam would lead the work of the party central committee, the politburo and the secretariat, according to the official announcement.\n\n\"The Politburo calls on the entire party, people and army to have absolute trust in the party's leadership and state management,\" the statement said.\n\n- Upheaval -\n\nThe country's communist regime, which is in the midst of a complete overhaul, has undergone a series of upheavals in recent months, with ministers, business leaders and two presidents all falling from grace as part of a vast anti-corruption campaign.\n\nLam served as Vietnam's public security minister before being voted in as president in May by Vietnam's rubber-stamp parliament after his predecessor was forced to resign.\n\nAnalysts said at the time that Lam, who was deputy head of the steering committee on anti-corruption matters, had weaponised investigations to take down his political rivals.\n\nIn his first remarks as president, Lam said he was \"determined to fight corruption and negative phenomena\".\n\nBenoit de Treglode, research director at the Institute for Strategic Research at France's military academy in Paris, told AFP Thursday that his designation as interim leader signalled \"the total victory of To Lam\".\n\n\"He is an extremely strong statesman, supported by a ministry at the heart of the Vietnamese political project,\" he said, adding that Lam's interim leadership could last until the party congress in January 2026.\n\n\"We will witness a personalisation of power around him, which will lead to political stability\" and a movement towards \"continuity, and not rupture\", he continued.\n\nHeaded by the party general secretary, Vietnam's leadership structure gives the president the second-most authority, and also includes the prime minister and the head of the National Assembly.\n\n- Hard line -\n\nTrong's poor health has fuelled widespread speculation that he will not be able to stay in power until the 2026 party congress, which is expected to appoint a successor.\n\nIn office since 2011, Trong has enjoyed remarkable longevity in his role, which rights groups say has coincided with increasing authoritarianism.\n\nKnown for being a technocrat and on good terms with Beijing, he had structured the party around himself, benefiting from a decade of economic growth that has strengthened his legitimacy.\n\nLam has long been considered one of the most serious candidates to succeed Trong, and was noted for the hard line he adopted when he was Minister of Public Security.\n\nThree years ago he caused a public outcry after a video was released showing him eating a steak covered in gold leaf at an upmarket London restaurant, shortly after laying a wreath at Karl Marx's grave.\n\nA few months later, the regime jailed a street vendor for posting a parody video that went viral.\n\nThere is little room for dissent against one-party rule in Vietnam, with critical voices subject to intimidation, harassment and travel restrictions.\n\nbur/srg/ah/smw", "source": {"uri": "Vietnam president handed power as party leader seeks medical care", "body": "Vietnam's communist regime handed the reins of power Thursday to the country's largely ceremonial president, as 80-year-old leader and party General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong temporarily stood down for health reasons.\n\nThe politburo appointed President To Lam to take over as both the party and country's caretaker leader, the party said in an online statement.\n\nLam was assigned to lead the works of the party central committee, the politburo and the secretariat, while Trong would \"focus on active treatment\".\n\n\"The Politburo calls on the entire party, people and army to have absolute trust in the party's leadership and state management,\" the statement said.\n\nIt gave no indication of how long Lam would be assigned to the role, nor did it address why Trong required medical treatment.\n\nThe country's communist regime, which is in the midst of a complete overhaul, has undergone a series of upheavals in recent months, with two presidents, ministers and business leaders falling from grace as part of a vast anti-corruption operation.\n\nHeaded by the Communist Party general secretary, Vietnam's leadership structure gives the president the second-most authority -- but the position is largely seen as ceremonial.\n\nThe communist government's hierarchy also includes the prime minister and the head of the National Assembly.\n\nMore from this section Top US senator found guilty of corruption Donald Trump makes appearance to greet supporters at Republican National Convention Leaked Trong, who has led Vietnamese politics since 2011, is known for his strong anti-corruption stance. Lam, a key figure in anti-graft efforts, is seen as Trong's likely successor.\n\nVietnamese President To Lam on Thursday stepped in as the caretaker of the Communist Party due to the poor health of party chief Nguyen Phu Trong, the party revealed in a statement.\n\nNguyen Phu Trong, elected to a third term as general secretary in 2021, has been a dominant force in Vietnamese politics since becoming party chief in 2011. Known for his stringent anti-corruption stance, Trong has long viewed graft as the primary threat to the party.\n\nAs Vietnam's top security official, Lam spearheaded Trong's extensive anti-graft campaign until May, when he ascended to the presidency following his predecessor's resignation amidst the campaign. Lam is now widely regarded as the top candidate to succeed Trong when his term concludes in 2026. With over four decades in the Ministry of Public Security and a pivotal role in enforcing anti-corruption measures, Lam's credentials are well-established.\n\nThe powerful Politburo has now tasked Lam with presiding over the work of the Party Central Committee, the Politburo, and the Secretariat, according to a statement from the party's central office.\n\nThe statement also confirmed the {"uri": "2024-07-427099271", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:53:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:53:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:30:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.wboc.com/news/international/vietnam-communist-party-chief-nguyen-phu-trong-the-countrys-most-powerful-leader-dies-at-age/article_76945a71-1049-5bd1-93c9-8c662831f389.html", "title": "Vietnam Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong, the country's most powerful leader, dies at age 80", "body": "FILE - Vietnamese President To Lam speaks during a press briefing with Russian President Vladimir Putin at the Presidential Palace in Hanoi, Vietnam, on June 20, 2024. To Lam on Thursday July 18, 2024 became the caretaker of the Communist Party because of party chief Nguyen Phu Trong's poor health, the party said in a statement.\n\nHANOI, Vietnam (AP) -- Nguyen Phu Trong, general secretary of Vietnam's ruling Communist Party and the country's most powerful politician, has died following months of ill health, official media said Friday. He was 80.\n\n\"General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Party Nguyen Phu Trong passed away at 13:38 on July 19, 2024, at the 108 Central Military Hospital due to old age and serious illness,\" the Nhan Dan newspaper said.\n\nOfficial media said a state funeral would be held.\n\nTrong had dominated Vietnamese politics since 2011, when he was elected party chief. During his tenure, he worked to consolidate the Communist Party's power in Vietnam's single-party political system. In the decade before he took the top role in Vietnamese politics, the balance of power had shifted more toward the governmental wing led by then-Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung.\n\nBorn in 1944 in Hanoi, Trong was a Marxist-Leninist ideologue who earned a degree in philosophy before becoming a member of the Communist Party at the age of 22. He viewed corruption as the single gravest threat in maintaining the party's legitimacy.\n\n\"A country without discipline would be chaotic and unstable,\" Trong said in 2016 after being reelected to the party's helm. Officially, Vietnam has no top leader, but the Communist Party chief is traditionally seen as the most powerful.\n\nHe launched a sweeping anti-corruption campaign known as the \"blazing furnace\" that singed both business and political elites. Since 2016, thousands of party officials have been disciplined. They included former presidents Nguyen Xuan Phuc and Vo Van Thuong and the former head of parliament, Vuong Dinh Hue. In all, eight members of the powerful Politburo were ousted on corruption allegations, compared to none between 1986 and 2016.\n\nTrong studied in the Soviet Union from 1981 to 1983, and there was speculation that under his leadership, Vietnam would move closer to Russia and China. However, the Southeast Asian nation followed a pragmatic policy of \"bamboo diplomacy,\" a phrase he coined that referred to the plant's flexibility, bending but not breaking in the shifting headwinds of geopolitics.\n\nVietnam maintained its traditional ties with its much larger neighbor, China, dispute differences over sovereignty in the South China Sea. But it also drew closer to the United States, elevating its ties with its former Vietnam War foe to its highest diplomatic status, a comprehensive strategic partnership.\n\nTrong's legacy is mixed, with the unintended consequence of the anti-graft campaign being an erosion of institutions within the Communist Party, said Nguyen Khac Giang, a visiting fellow in the Vietnam Studies Program at Singapore's ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute. The party institutions were the bedrock ensuring that a balance of power remained among its different factions, he said.\n\n\"Vietnam has become more and more like China, where institutions and norms doesn't really matter as much as personal power,\" Giang said.\n\nVietanamese President To Lam was appointed the party caretaker on July 18 while Trong received treatment for his ill health. As Vietnam's top security official, Lam had led the anti-graft campaign until becoming president in May, when his predecessor resigned after being caught up in it.\n\nThe party's Politburo asked Lam to \"preside over the work of the Party Central Committee, the Politburo, and the Secretariat,\" according to a statement from its central office which was the first official confirmation of Trong's poor health.\n\nRumors about his health have swirled in Vietnamese politics since he was first hospitalized in 2019, and more recently when he appeared extremely frail while meeting visiting Russian President Vladmir Putin.\n\nTrong' death leaves behind a yawning political vacuum in Vietnam. Although Lam is widely viewed as the likely next party chief, Giang predicted \"a very uncertain time\" in Vietnamese politics because the norms and institutions governing the country are \"very shaky.\"\n\n\"Now it isn't only about the rules or norms, but it is also about who holds the most power,\" Giang said.", "source": {"uri": "wboc.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "WBOC TV-16"}, {"uri": "2024-07-425838567", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "10:26:54", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T10:26:54Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T10:17:37Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8156862854957581, "url": "https://www.cnn.com/2024/07/18/asia/vietnam-president-lam-takeover-trong-health-intl/index.html", "title": "Vietnam Communist Party chief hands power to president as he undergoes medical care", "body": "Vietnamese President To Lam attends a press briefing at the Presidential Palace in Hanoi, Vietnam on June 20.\n\nVietnam's President To Lam has taken over the duties of Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong who is focusing on an unspecified treatment for his health, the party said on Thursday.\n\nThe extraordinary move comes after months of speculation that Trong's health was weakening. The party did not clarify what treatment he is receiving.\n\nLam, a former head of internal security, has been widely seen as a top candidate to replace Trong when his term ends in 2026. The party's powerful Politburo has tasked him with presiding over \"the work of the Party Central Committee, the Politburo and the Secretariat,\" according to a statement from the party's central office.\n\nThough Vietnam officially has no paramount ruler, the party chief holds the most powerful position in the Communist-ruled nation. Trong, 80, has been in the post since 2011.\n\nVietnam's Communist Party General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong at the Communist Party of Vietnam Headquarters in Hanoi, Vietnam on September 10, 2023.\n\nEvelyn Hockstein/Reuters\n\nTrong, a Marxist-Leninist ideologue, has since 2017 unleashed what many see as a China-style crackdown on corruption known as \"blazing furnace\". But in recent months, he has appeared fragile in public events and missed several top-level meetings.\n\nIn a surprise move, the Politburo awarded Trong on Thursday with the Gold Star medal, the country's highest honor for public officials.\n\nLam was elected president in May after several top leaders quit amid accusations of unspecified wrongdoing, part of the sweeping anti-graft campaign launched by Trong.\n\nLam, a key player in the crackdown, promised after his election to \"resolutely and persistently continue the fight against corruption\".\n\nVietnam's main stock market edged up 0.5% after the announcement.\n\nA Hanoi-based senior Western diplomat said he saw Lam's expanded powers as \"Good for stability.\"\n\nBut the diplomat, who declined to be identified, added: \"We'll {"uri": "8233532056", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "12:50:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T12:50:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T12:50:10Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8117647171020508, "url": "https://www.castanet.net/news/World/497773/Vietnam-Communist-Party-chief-Nguyen-Phu-Trong-the-country-s-most-powerful-leader-dies-at-age-80", "title": "Vietnam Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong, the country's most powerful leader, dies at age 80 - World News", "body": "Photo: The Canadian Press FILE - Vietnamese General Secretary of the Communist Party Nguyen Phu Trong addresses the media in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Sept. 10, 2023. Vietnamese President To Lam on Thursday July 18, 2024 became the caretaker of the Communist Party because of Trong's poor health, the party said in a statement. (Luong Thai Linh/Pool Photo via AP, File)\n\nNguyen Phu Trong, general secretary of Vietnam's ruling Communist Party and the country's most powerful politician, has died following months of ill health, official media said Friday. He was 80.\n\n\"General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Party Nguyen Phu Trong passed away at 13:38 on July 19, 2024, at the 108 Central Military Hospital due to old age and serious illness,\" the Nhan Dan newspaper said.\n\nOfficial media said a state funeral would be held.\n\nTrong had dominated Vietnamese politics since 2011, when he was elected party chief. During his tenure, he worked to consolidate the Communist Party's power in Vietnam's single-party political system. In the decade before he took the top role in Vietnamese politics, the balance of power had shifted more toward the governmental wing led by then-Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung.\n\nBorn in 1944 in Hanoi, Trong was a Marxist-Leninist ideologue who earned a degree in philosophy before becoming a member of the Communist Party at the age of 22. He viewed corruption as the single gravest threat in maintaining the party's legitimacy.\n\n\"A country without discipline would be chaotic and unstable,\" Trong said in 2016 after being reelected to the party's helm. Officially, Vietnam has no top leader, but the Communist Party chief is traditionally seen as the most powerful.\n\nHe launched a sweeping anti-corruption campaign known as the \"blazing furnace\" that singed both business and political elites. Since 2016, thousands of party officials have been disciplined. They included former presidents Nguyen Xuan Phuc and Vo Van Thuong and the former head of parliament, Vuong Dinh Hue. In all, eight members of the powerful Politburo were ousted on corruption allegations, compared to none between 1986 and 2016.\n\nTrong studied in the Soviet Union from 1981 to 1983, and there was speculation that under his leadership, Vietnam would move closer to Russia and China. However, the Southeast Asian nation followed a pragmatic policy of \"bamboo diplomacy,\" a phrase he coined that referred to the plant's flexibility, bending but not breaking in the shifting headwinds of geopolitics.\n\nVietnam maintained its traditional ties with its much larger neighbor, China, dispute differences over sovereignty in the South China Sea. But it also drew closer to the United States, elevating its ties with its former Vietnam War foe to its highest diplomatic status, a comprehensive strategic partnership.\n\nTrong's legacy is mixed, with the unintended consequence of the anti-graft campaign being an erosion of institutions within the Communist Party, said Nguyen Khac Giang, a visiting fellow in the Vietnam Studies Program at Singapore's ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute. The party institutions were the bedrock ensuring that a balance of power remained among its different factions, he said.\n\n\"Vietnam has become more and more like China, where institutions and norms doesn't really matter as much as personal power,\" Giang said.\n\nVietanamese President To Lam was appointed the party caretaker on July 18 while Trong received treatment for his ill health. As Vietnam's top security official, Lam had led the anti-graft campaign until becoming president in May, when his predecessor resigned after being caught up in it.\n\nThe party's Politburo asked Lam to \"preside over the work of the Party Central Committee, the Politburo, and the Secretariat,\" according to a statement from its central office which was the first official confirmation of Trong's poor health.\n\nRumors about his health have swirled in Vietnamese politics since he was first hospitalized in 2019, and more recently when he appeared extremely frail while meeting visiting Russian President Vladmir Putin.\n\nTrong' death leaves behind a yawning political vacuum in Vietnam. Although Lam is widely viewed as the likely next party chief, Giang predicted \"a very uncertain time\" in Vietnamese politics because the norms and institutions governing the country are \"very shaky.\"\n\n\"Now it isn't only about the rules or norms, but it is also about who holds the most power,\" Giang said.", "source": {"uri": "castanet.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "Castanet"}, "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.kulr8.com/news/national/vietnam-president-handed-power-as-party-leader-seeks-medical-care/article_c5b58bb6-dfcb-5a3b-8d93-5292e2e3191a.html", "title": "Vietnam president handed power as party leader seeks medical care", "body": "Vietnam's communist regime handed the reins of power Thursday to the country's largely ceremonial president, as 80-year-old leader and party General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong temporarily stood down for health reasons.\n\nThe politburo appointed President To Lam to take over as both the party and country's caretaker leader, the party said in an online statement.\n\nLam was assigned to lead the works of the party central committee, the politburo and the secretariat, while Trong would \"focus on active treatment\".\n\n\"The Politburo calls on the entire party, people and army to have absolute trust in the party's leadership and state management,\" the statement said.\n\nIt gave no indication of how long Lam would be assigned to the role, nor did it address why Trong required medical treatment.\n\nThe country's communist regime, which is in the midst of a complete overhaul, has undergone a series of upheavals in recent months, with two presidents, ministers and business leaders falling from grace as part of a vast anti-corruption operation.\n\nHeaded by the Communist Party general secretary, Vietnam's leadership structure gives the president the second-most authority -- but the position is largely seen as ceremonial.\n\nThe communist government's hierarchy also includes the prime minister and the head of the National Assembly.\n\nTrong's poor health has fuelled widespread speculation that he will not be able to stay in power until the 2026 party congress that is expected to appoint a successor.\n\nIn office since 2011, the party leader has enjoyed remarkable longevity in his role, which rights groups say has coincided with increasing authoritarianism.\n\nKnown for being a technocrat and on good terms with Beijing, Trong had structured the party around himself, benefiting from a decade of economic growth that has strengthened his legitimacy.\n\nLam, 67, served as Vietnam's public security minister before being voted in as president in May by Vietnam's rubber-stamp parliament after his predecessor was forced to resign in a major anti-corruption campaign.\n\nAnalysts said at the time that Lam, who was deputy head of the steering committee on anti-corruption matters, had weaponised investigations to take down his political rivals.\n\nIn his {"uri": "2024-07-427092771", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:47:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:47:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:11:33Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3022894-vietnams-transformational-leader-nguyen-phu-trong-passes-away", "title": "Vietnam's Transformational Leader Nguyen Phu Trong Passes Away", "body": "Vietnam's Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong has died at the age of 80. Trong, who held the country's most powerful position for 13 years, passed away after a prolonged illness. His tenure was marked by significant political influence and a major anti-corruption campaign.\n\nVietnam's Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong has died at the age of 80, state media reported on Friday. Trong had held the nation's most powerful position for 13 years.\n\nState media, citing Trong's medical team, confirmed he passed away early Friday due to 'old age and serious illness.'\n\nPresident To Lam assumed Trong's responsibilities on Thursday as the aging leader focused on medical treatment. Trong, educated in the Soviet Union, had been the pivotal figure in Vietnam's Communist regime since 2011 and secured a rare third term in 2021, underscoring his political dominance. In recent months, his public appearances had become increasingly scarce due to his frail health.\n\nThe party must decide if Lam will serve as acting general secretary until the next Congress in 2026 or elect a new leader earlier. Trong's legacy includes a 2017 anti-corruption drive, dubbed the 'blazing furnace,' which implicated hundreds of officials, including high-profile resignations. {"uri": "8233577958", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "13:26:00", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T13:26:00Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T13:20:48Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.8078431487083435, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13651695/Vietnam-Communist-Party-chief-Nguyen-Phu-Trong-countrys-powerful-leader-dies-age-80.html", "title": "Vietnam Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong, the country's most...", "body": "HANOI, Vietnam (AP) - Nguyen Phu Trong, general secretary of Vietnam\u00b4s ruling Communist Party and the country\u00b4s most powerful politician, has died following months of ill health, official media said Friday. He was 80.\n\n\"General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Party Nguyen Phu Trong passed away at 13:38 on July 19, 2024, at the 108 Central Military Hospital due to old age and serious illness,\" the Nhan Dan newspaper said.\n\nOfficial media said a state funeral would be held.\n\nTrong had dominated Vietnamese politics since 2011, when he was elected party chief. During his tenure, he worked to consolidate the Communist Party\u00b4s power in Vietnam\u00b4s single-party political system. In the decade before he took the top role in Vietnamese politics, the balance of power had shifted more toward the governmental wing led by then-Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung.\n\nBorn in 1944 in Hanoi, Trong was a Marxist-Leninist ideologue who earned a degree in philosophy before becoming a member of the Communist Party at the age of 22. He viewed corruption as the single gravest threat in maintaining the party\u00b4s legitimacy.\n\n\"A country without discipline would be chaotic and unstable,\" Trong said in 2016 after being reelected to the party\u00b4s helm. Officially, Vietnam has no top leader, but the Communist Party chief is traditionally seen as the most powerful.\n\nFILE - Vietnamese General Secretary of the Communist Party Nguyen Phu Trong addresses the media in Hanoi, Vietnam, on Sept. 10, 2023. The powerful head of Vietnam's ruling Communist Party, has died, official media say on Friday, July 19, 2024. (Luong Thai Linh/Pool Photo via AP, File)\n\nHe launched a sweeping anti-corruption campaign known as the \"blazing furnace\" that singed both business and political elites. Since 2016, thousands of party officials have been disciplined. They included former presidents Nguyen Xuan Phuc and Vo Van Thuong and the former head of parliament, Vuong Dinh Hue. In all, eight members of the powerful Politburo were ousted on corruption allegations, compared to none between 1986 and 2016.\n\nTrong studied in the Soviet Union from 1981 to 1983, and there was speculation that under his leadership, Vietnam would move closer to Russia and China. However, the Southeast Asian nation followed a pragmatic policy of \"bamboo diplomacy,\" a phrase he coined that referred to the plant\u00b4s flexibility, bending but not breaking in the shifting headwinds of geopolitics.\n\nVietnam maintained its traditional ties with its much larger neighbor, China, dispute differences over sovereignty in the South China Sea. But it also drew closer to the United States, elevating its ties with its former Vietnam War foe to its highest diplomatic status, a comprehensive strategic partnership.\n\nTrong\u00b4s legacy is mixed, with the unintended consequence of the anti-graft campaign being an erosion of institutions within the Communist Party, said Nguyen Khac Giang, a visiting fellow in the Vietnam Studies Program at Singapore\u00b4s ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute. The party institutions were the bedrock ensuring that a balance of power remained among its different factions, he said.\n\n\"Vietnam has become more and more like China, where institutions and norms doesn\u00b4t really matter as much as personal power,\" Giang said.\n\nVietanamese President To Lam was appointed the party caretaker on July 18 while Trong received treatment for his ill health. As Vietnam\u00b4s top security official, Lam had led the anti-graft campaign until becoming president in May, when his predecessor resigned after being caught up in it.\n\nThe party\u00b4s Politburo asked Lam to \"preside over the work of the Party Central Committee, the Politburo, and the Secretariat,\" according to a statement from its central office which was the first official confirmation of Trong\u00b4s poor health.\n\nRumors about his health have swirled in Vietnamese politics since he was first hospitalized in 2019, and more recently when he appeared extremely frail while meeting visiting Russian President Vladmir Putin.\n\nTrong\u00b4 death leaves behind a yawning political vacuum in Vietnam. Although Lam is widely viewed as the likely next party chief, Giang predicted \"a very uncertain time\" in Vietnamese politics because the norms and institutions governing the country are \"very shaky.\"\n\n\"Now it isn\u00b4t only about the rules or norms, but it is also about who holds the most power,\" Giang said.\n\nFILE - Vietnamese President To Lam speaks during a press briefing with Russian President Vladimir Putin at the Presidential Palace in Hanoi, Vietnam, on June 20, 2024. To Lam on Thursday July 18, 2024 became the caretaker of the Communist Party because of party chief Nguyen Phu Trong's poor health, the party said in a statement. (AP Photo/Minh Hoang, Pool, File)", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail Online"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Hanoi"}, "location": {"type": "place", "label": {"eng": "Hanoi"}, "country": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Vietnam"}}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Vietnam", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Vietnam"}, "location": {"type": "country", "label": {"eng": "Vietnam"}}}, {"uri": to 'focus' on health, caretaker assigned: party", "body": "Vietnam's 80-year-old leader and Communist Party General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong will take a break to \"focus\" on his health, the party said on Thursday.\n\nPresident To Lam would take over as the country's caretaker leader, the party said in an online statement.\n\nThe party said Lam had been assigned to lead the works of the party central committee, the politburo, the secretariat, while Trong would \"focus on active treatment\".\n\nLed by the Communist Party general secretary, Vietnam's leadership structure gives the president the second-most authority -- but the position is largely seen as ceremonial.\n\nThe communist government's four-person hierarchy also includes the prime minister and the head of the National Assembly.\n\nTrong's ailing health has fuelled widespread speculation that he will not be able to stay in power until the 2026 party congress that is expected to appoint a successor.\n\nIn office since 2011, the party leader has enjoyed remarkable longevity in his role, which rights groups say has coincided with Vietnam's drift toward authoritarianism.\n\nLam, 67, served as Vietnam's public security minister before being voted in as president by Vietnam's rubber-stamp parliament after a major anti-corruption campaign forced his predecessor to resign.\n\nThousands of people -- including several senior government and business leaders -- have been caught up in the Southeast Asian country's crackdown on graft, led by Trong.\n\nAnalysts have said that Lam, who is deputy head of the steering committee on anti-corruption, has weaponised its investigations to take down his political rivals.\n\nIn his first remarks as president, Lam said he was \"determined to fight corruption and negative phenomena\".\n\nbur/srg/fox\n\nMore from this section\n\nFoundation for a Drug-Free World Drug Prevention Nonprofit Earns Consultative Status to the UN\n\n[Updated!] Pokemon GO Failed to {"uri": "2024-07-427414018", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:03:43", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:03:43Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T12:00:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.newsmax.com/newsfront/vietnam-communist-party-chief/2024/07/19/id/1173212/", "title": "Powerful Vietnam Communist Party Chief Trong Dies", "body": "Nguyen Phu Trong, general secretary of Vietnam's ruling Communist Party and the country's most powerful politician, died after months of ill health, official media said Friday. He was 80.\n\n\"General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Party Nguyen Phu Trong passed away at 13:38 on July 19, 2024, at the 108 Central Military Hospital due to old age and serious illness,\" the Nhan Dan newspaper said.\n\nOfficial media said a state funeral will be held.\n\nTrong had dominated Vietnamese politics since 2011, when he was elected party chief. During his tenure, he worked to consolidate the Communist Party's power in Vietnam's single-party political system. In the decade before he took the top role in Vietnamese politics, the balance of power had shifted more toward the governmental wing led by then-Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung.\n\nBorn in 1944 in Hanoi, Trong was a Marxist-Leninist ideologue who earned a degree in philosophy before becoming a member of the Communist Party at the age of 22. He viewed corruption as the single gravest threat in maintaining the party's legitimacy.\n\n\"A country without discipline would be chaotic and unstable,\" Trong said in 2016 after being reelected to the party's helm. Officially, Vietnam has no top leader, but the Communist Party chief is traditionally seen as the most powerful.\n\nHe launched a sweeping anti-corruption campaign known as the \"blazing furnace\" that singed both business and political elites. Since 2016, thousands of party officials have been disciplined. They included former presidents Nguyen Xuan Phuc and Vo Van Thuong and the former head of parliament, Vuong Dinh Hue. In all, eight members of the powerful Politburo were ousted on corruption allegations, compared to none between 1986 and 2016.\n\nTrong studied in the Soviet Union from 1981 to 1983, and there was speculation that under his leadership, Vietnam would move closer to Russia and China. However, the Southeast Asian nation followed a pragmatic policy of \"bamboo diplomacy,\" a phrase he coined that referred to the plant's flexibility, bending but not breaking in the shifting headwinds of geopolitics.\n\nVietnam maintained its traditional ties with its much larger neighbor, China, dispute differences over sovereignty in the South China Sea. But it also drew closer to the United States, elevating its ties with its former Vietnam War foe to its highest diplomatic status, a comprehensive strategic partnership.\n\nTrong's legacy is mixed, with the unintended consequence of the anti-graft campaign being an erosion of institutions within the Communist Party, said Nguyen Khac Giang, a visiting fellow in the Vietnam Studies Program at Singapore's ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute. The party institutions were the bedrock ensuring that a balance of power remained among its different factions, he said.\n\n\"Vietnam has become more and more like China, where institutions and norms doesn't really matter as much as personal power,\" Giang said.\n\nVietnamese President To Lam was appointed the party caretaker on July 18 while Trong received treatment for his ill health. As Vietnam's top security official, Lam had led the anti-graft campaign until becoming president in May, when his predecessor resigned after being caught up in it.\n\nThe party's Politburo asked Lam to \"preside over the work of the Party Central Committee, the Politburo, and the Secretariat,\" according to a statement from its central office which was the first official confirmation of Trong's poor health.\n\nRumors about his health have swirled in Vietnamese politics since he was first hospitalized in 2019, and more recently when he appeared extremely frail while meeting visiting Russian President Vladmir Putin.\n\nTrong' death leaves behind a yawning political vacuum in Vietnam. Although Lam is widely viewed as the likely next party chief, Giang predicted \"a very uncertain time\" in Vietnamese politics because the norms and institutions governing the country are \"very shaky.\"\n\n\"Now it isn't only about the rules or norms, but it is also about who holds the most power,\" Giang said.", "source": {"uri": "newsmax.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NewsMax"}, {"uri": "2024-07-427091366", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:46:01", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:46:01Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:25:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7960784435272217, "url": "https://www.register-herald.com/news/nation_world/vietnam-communist-party-chief-nguyen-phu-trong-the-countrys-most-powerful-leader-dies-at-age/article_938f105e-d7c9-5997-8444-99af846473c8.html", "title": "Vietnam Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong, the country's most powerful leader, dies at age 80", "body": "FILE - Vietnamese President To Lam speaks during a press briefing with Russian President Vladimir Putin at the Presidential Palace in Hanoi, Vietnam, on June 20, 2024. To Lam on Thursday July 18, 2024 became the caretaker of the Communist Party because of party chief Nguyen Phu Trong's poor health, the party said in a statement.\n\nHANOI, Vietnam (AP) -- Nguyen Phu Trong, general secretary of Vietnam's ruling Communist Party and the country's most powerful politician, has died following months of ill health, official media said Friday. He was 80.\n\n\"General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Party Nguyen Phu Trong passed away at 13:38 on July 19, 2024, at the 108 Central Military Hospital due to old age and serious illness,\" the Nhan Dan newspaper said.\n\nTrong had dominated Vietnamese politics since 2011, when he was elected party chief. During his tenure, he worked to consolidate the Communist Party's power in Vietnam's single-party political system. In the decade before he took the top role in Vietnamese politics, the balance of power had shifted more toward the governmental wing led by then-Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung.\n\nBorn in 1944 in Hanoi, Trong was a Marxist-Leninist ideologue who earned a degree in philosophy before becoming a member of the Communist Party at the age of 22. He viewed corruption as the single gravest threat in maintaining the party's legitimacy.\n\n\"A country without discipline would be chaotic and unstable,\" Trong said in 2016 after being reelected to the party's helm. Officially, Vietnam has no top leader, but the Communist Party chief is traditionally seen as the most powerful.\n\nHe launched a sweeping anti-corruption campaign known as the \"blazing furnace\" that singed both business and political elites. Since 2016, thousands of party officials have been disciplined. They included former presidents Nguyen Xuan Phuc and Vo Van Thuong and the former head of parliament, Vuong Dinh Hue. In all, eight members of the powerful Politburo were ousted on corruption allegations, compared to none between 1986 and 2016.\n\nTrong studied in the Soviet Union from 1981 to 1983, and there was speculation that under his leadership, Vietnam would move closer to Russia and China. However, the Southeast Asian nation followed a pragmatic policy of \"bamboo diplomacy,\" a phrase he coined that referred to the plant's flexibility, bending but not breaking in the shifting headwinds of geopolitics.\n\nVietnam maintained its traditional ties with its much larger neighbor, China, dispute differences over sovereignty in the South China Sea. But it also drew closer to the United States, elevating its ties with its former Vietnam War foe to its highest diplomatic status, a comprehensive strategic partnership.", "source": {"uri": {"uri": "8233663243", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "14:18:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T14:18:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T14:17:58Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://www.theguardian.com/world/article/2024/jul/19/vietnams-communist-leader-nguyen-phu-trong-dies-aged-80-creating-vast-power-vacuum", "title": "Vietnam's Communist leader dies aged 80 creating vast power vacuum", "body": "Nguyen Phu Trong, one of the country's longest-serving politicians, died on Friday due to old age and illness\n\nNguyen Phu Trong, the general secretary of Vietnam's ruling Communist party and the country's most powerful politician, has died aged 80, creating a power vacuum.\n\nTrong died early on Friday afternoon \"after a period of illness\", according to his medical team, state media reported.\n\nTrong held Vietnam's most powerful position, general-secretary of Vietnam's ruling Communist party, since 2011, one of the longest-serving leaders in decades. He also served as president from 2018 to 2021.\n\nDuring his time in office, he oversaw a period of rapid economic growth as well as a balancing of ties with China and Vietnam's former foe, the US. Trong was known for his \"blazing furnace\" anti-corruption drive, under which even senior political figures, including former presidents, were forced to resign.\n\nThere had been speculation about Trong's health for months, fuelled by his absences from recent meetings.\n\n\"General secretary of the Central Committee of the Party, Nguyen Phu Trong, passed away at 13:38 on 19 July 2024, at the 108 Central Military hospital due to old age and serious illness,\" the Nhan Dan newspaper said.\n\nOn Thursday, it was announced he would step back from his role as head of the Communist party, due to unspecified health concerns, with president To Lam instead taking over his duties. Trong was awarded the Gold Star medal, the country's highest honour for public officials, on the same day.\n\nTrong will be remembered for his anti-corruption campaigns, which were unprecedented in the history of the party. Since 2016, more than 139,000 party members have been punished for corruption - a crackdown so vast it was blamed for negative impacts on the economy, with officials reluctant to sign off approvals, fearful of being accused of wrongdoing.\n\nIn pursuing such crackdowns, he \"consolidated an unrivalled level of power within the political system,\" said Nguyen Khac Giang, a visiting fellow at the Vietnam studies programme of the ISEAS - Yusof Ishak Institute in Singapore.\n\nAny plans that he had for an orderly succession transition had gone unrealised, he added, and his death risks creating a power vacuum.\n\nGiang added: \"I think this will lead [to] a very difficult time for Vietnam, for the political allies to negotiate among themselves who will assume the position of Nguyen Phu Trong. That might lead to a succession crisis where different factions would not agree.\"\n\nGiven Trong's power and popularity, analysts say any successor is unlikely to deviate from his policies in relation to the economy, foreign policy, or the lack of tolerance for government critics.\n\nThere are now more than 160 people held in prison for peacefully exercising their civil and political rights, according to Human Rights Watch.\n\nThe courts convicted at least 28 rights campaigners and sentenced them to long prison terms during the first 10 months of 2023, the group said.\n\nIn his foreign policy, Trong pursued a so-called \"bamboo diplomacy\" - which 'sways with the winds' and avoids picking sides in international disputes - including in relation to the rivalry between the US and China.\n\nIn 2015, he became the first general secretary of the Communist party to pay an official visit to the US, where he met with the former president Barack Obama.\n\nLast year Trong hosted the US president, Joe Biden, and upgraded ties with Washington, as well as with Australia and Japan. China's president, Xi Jinping, also made a state visit three months later.\n\nChina's Communist party central committee said the Chinese people had lost a \"good comrade, brother and friend\", Chinese state media reported.", "source": {"uri": "theguardian.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Guardian"}, "authors": [{"uri": "rebecca_ratcliffe@theguardian.com", "name": "Rebecca Ratcliffe", "type": {"uri": "2024-07-427236592", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "14:02:19", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T14:02:19Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:17:51Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7921568751335144, "url": "https://tribtown.com/2024/07/19/vietnam-communist-party-chief-nguyen-phu-trong-the-countrys-most-powerful-leader-dies-at-age-80/", "title": "Vietnam Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong, the country's most powerful leader, dies at age 80", "body": "HANOI, Vietnam (AP) -- Nguyen Phu Trong, general secretary of Vietnam's ruling Communist Party and the country's most powerful politician, has died following months of ill health, official media said Friday. He was 80.\n\n\"General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Party Nguyen Phu Trong passed away at 13:38 on July 19, 2024, at the 108 Central Military Hospital due to old age and serious illness,\" the Nhan Dan newspaper said.\n\nOfficial media said a state funeral would be held.\n\nTrong had dominated Vietnamese politics since 2011, when he was elected party chief. During his tenure, he worked to consolidate the Communist Party's power in Vietnam's single-party political system. In the decade before he took the top role in Vietnamese politics, the balance of power had shifted more toward the governmental wing led by then-Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung.\n\nBorn in 1944 in Hanoi, Trong was a Marxist-Leninist ideologue who earned a degree in philosophy before becoming a member of the Communist Party at the age of 22. He viewed corruption as the single gravest threat in maintaining the party's legitimacy.\n\n\"A country without discipline would be chaotic and unstable,\" Trong said in 2016 after being reelected to the party's helm. Officially, Vietnam has no top leader, but the Communist Party chief is traditionally seen as the most powerful.\n\nHe launched a sweeping anti-corruption campaign known as the \"blazing furnace\" that singed both business and political elites. Since 2016, thousands of party officials have been disciplined. They included former presidents Nguyen Xuan Phuc and Vo Van Thuong and the former head of parliament, Vuong Dinh Hue. In all, eight members of the powerful Politburo were ousted on corruption allegations, compared to none between 1986 and 2016.\n\nTrong studied in the Soviet Union from 1981 to 1983, and there was speculation that under his leadership, Vietnam would move closer to Russia and China. However, the Southeast Asian nation followed a pragmatic policy of \"bamboo diplomacy,\" a phrase he coined that referred to the plant's flexibility, bending but not breaking in the shifting headwinds of geopolitics.\n\nVietnam maintained its traditional ties with its much larger neighbor, China, dispute differences over sovereignty in the South China Sea. But it also drew closer to the United States, elevating its ties with its former Vietnam War foe to its highest diplomatic status, a comprehensive strategic partnership.\n\nTrong's legacy is mixed, with the unintended consequence of the anti-graft campaign being an erosion of institutions within the Communist Party, said Nguyen Khac Giang, a visiting fellow in the Vietnam Studies Program at Singapore's ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute. The party institutions were the bedrock ensuring that a balance of power remained among its different factions, he said.\n\n\"Vietnam has become more and more like China, where institutions and norms doesn't really matter as much as personal power,\" Giang said.\n\nVietanamese President To Lam was appointed the party caretaker on July 18 while Trong received treatment for his ill health. As Vietnam's top security official, Lam had led the anti-graft campaign until becoming president in May, when his predecessor resigned after being caught up in it.\n\nThe party's Politburo asked Lam to \"preside over the work of the Party Central Committee, the Politburo, and the Secretariat,\" according to a statement from its central office which was the first official confirmation of Trong's poor health.\n\nRumors about his health have swirled in Vietnamese politics since he was first hospitalized in 2019, and more recently when he appeared extremely frail while meeting visiting Russian President Vladmir Putin.\n\nTrong' death leaves behind a yawning political vacuum in Vietnam. Although Lam is widely viewed as the likely next party chief, Giang predicted \"a very uncertain time\" in Vietnamese politics because the norms and institutions governing the country are \"very shaky.\"\n\n\"Now it isn't only about the rules or norms, but it is also about who holds the most power,\" Giang said.\n\nThe central committee of the Chinese Communist Party sent its condolences to its Vietnamese counterpart and \"deeply mourned\" Trong's death, the state-run Xinhua news agency reported Friday.", "source": {"uri": "tribtown.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Tribune"}, "sim": 0.7882353067398071, "url": "https://www.reformer.com/news/national/vietnam-president-handed-power-as-party-leader-seeks-medical-care/article_92d24a8e-fe02-50c3-866c-38a6349b4c38.html", "title": "Vietnam president handed power as party leader seeks medical care", "body": "President To Lam is taking Vietnam's reins temporarily while its current leader receives medical treatment\n\nVietnam's communist party handed the reins of power Thursday to the country's largely ceremonial president, To Lam, as its 80-year-old leader and general secretary temporarily stood down for health reasons.\n\nThe politburo appointed Lam, 67, to take over as both the party and country's caretaker leader while current General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong focused \"on active treatment\", the Vietnamese Communist Party said in an online statement.\n\nThe party gave no indication of how long Lam would be assigned to the role, nor did it address why Trong required medical treatment.\n\nBut one analyst suggested the rare announcement on the sensitive issue signalled the arrival of a new leader who could remain in power for years to come, calling it a \"total victory\" for Lam.\n\nLam would lead the work of the party central committee, the politburo and the secretariat, according to the official announcement.\n\n\"The Politburo calls on the entire party, people and army to have absolute trust in the party's leadership and state management,\" the statement said.\n\n- Upheaval -\n\nThe country's communist regime, which is in the midst of a complete overhaul, has undergone a series of upheavals in recent months, with ministers, business leaders and two presidents all falling from grace as part of a vast anti-corruption campaign.\n\nLam served as Vietnam's public security minister before being voted in as president in May by Vietnam's rubber-stamp parliament after his predecessor was forced to resign.\n\nAnalysts said at the time that Lam, who was deputy head of the steering committee on anti-corruption matters, had weaponised investigations to take down his political rivals.\n\nIn his first remarks as president, Lam said he was \"determined to fight corruption and negative phenomena\".\n\nBenoit de Treglode, research director at the Institute for Strategic Research at France's military academy in Paris, told AFP Thursday that his designation as interim leader signalled \"the total victory of To Lam\".\n\nMore from this section East Fishkill mourns retired Det. Mark DiDato Wildfire at major military gunnery range in Burlington and Ocean counties burns over 1,100 acres Here's Why Your Vote in the 2024 Election Is Crucial\n\n\"He is an extremely strong statesman, supported by a ministry at the heart of the Vietnamese political project,\" he said, adding that Lam's interim leadership could last until the party congress in January 2026.\n\n\"We will witness a personalisation of power around him, which will lead to political stability\" and a movement towards \"continuity, and not rupture\", he continued.\n\nHeaded by the party general secretary, Vietnam's leadership structure gives the president the second-most authority, and also includes the prime minister and the head of the National Assembly.\n\n- Hard line -\n\nTrong's poor health has fuelled widespread speculation that he will not be able to stay in power until the 2026 party congress, which is expected to appoint a successor.\n\nIn office since 2011, Trong has enjoyed remarkable longevity in his role, which rights groups say has coincided with increasing authoritarianism.\n\nKnown for being a technocrat and on good terms with Beijing, he had structured the party around himself, benefiting from a decade of economic growth that has strengthened his legitimacy.\n\nLam has long been considered one of the most serious candidates to succeed Trong, and was noted for the hard line he adopted when he was Minister of Public Security.\n\nThree years ago he caused a public outcry after a video was released showing him eating a steak covered in gold leaf at an upmarket London restaurant, shortly after laying a wreath at Karl Marx's grave.\n\nA few months later, the regime jailed a street vendor for posting a parody video that went viral.\n\nThere is little room for dissent against one-party rule in Vietnam, with critical voices subject to intimidation, harassment and travel restrictions.\n\nbur/srg/ah/smw", "source": {"uri": "reformer.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Vietnam president handed power as party leader seeks medical care", "body": "President To Lam is taking Vietnam's reins temporarily while its current leader receives medical treatment\n\nVietnam's communist party handed the reins of power Thursday to the country's largely ceremonial president, To Lam, as its 80-year-old leader and general secretary temporarily stood down for health reasons.\n\nThe politburo appointed Lam, 67, to take over as both the party and country's caretaker leader while current General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong focused \"on active treatment\", the Vietnamese Communist Party said in an online statement.\n\nThe party gave no indication of how long Lam would be assigned to the role, nor did it address why Trong required medical treatment.\n\nBut one analyst suggested the rare announcement on the sensitive issue signalled the arrival of a new leader who could remain in power for years to come, calling it a \"total victory\" for Lam.\n\nLam would lead the work of the party central committee, the politburo and the secretariat, according to the official announcement.\n\n\"The Politburo calls on the entire party, people and army to have absolute trust in the party's leadership and state management,\" the statement said.\n\n- Upheaval -\n\nThe country's communist regime, which is in the midst of a complete overhaul, has undergone a series of upheavals in recent months, with ministers, business leaders and two presidents all falling from grace as part of a vast anti-corruption campaign.\n\nLam served as Vietnam's public security minister before being voted in as president in May by Vietnam's rubber-stamp parliament after his predecessor was forced to resign.\n\nAnalysts said at the time that Lam, who was deputy head of the steering committee on anti-corruption matters, had weaponised investigations to take down his political rivals.\n\nIn his first remarks as president, Lam said he was \"determined to fight corruption and negative phenomena\".\n\nBenoit de Treglode, research director at the Institute for Strategic Research at France's military academy in Paris, told AFP Thursday that his designation as interim leader signalled \"the total victory of To Lam\".\n\n\"He is an extremely strong statesman, supported by a ministry at the heart of the Vietnamese political project,\" he said, adding that Lam's interim leadership could last until the party congress in January 2026.\n\n\"We will witness a personalisation of power around him, which will lead to political stability\" and a movement towards \"continuity, and not rupture\", he continued.\n\nHeaded by the party general secretary, Vietnam's leadership structure gives the president the second-most authority, and also includes the prime minister and the head of the National Assembly.\n\n- Hard line -\n\nTrong's poor health has fuelled widespread speculation that he will not be able to stay in power until the 2026 party congress, which is expected to appoint a successor.\n\nIn office since 2011, Trong has enjoyed remarkable longevity in his role, which rights groups say has coincided with increasing authoritarianism.\n\nKnown for being a technocrat and on good terms with Beijing, he had structured the party around himself, benefiting from a decade of economic growth that has strengthened his legitimacy.\n\nLam has long been considered one of the most serious candidates to succeed Trong, and was noted for the hard line he adopted when he was Minister of Public Security.\n\nThree years ago he caused a public outcry after a video was released showing him eating a steak covered in gold leaf at an upmarket London restaurant, shortly after laying a wreath at Karl Marx's grave.\n\nA few months later, the regime jailed a street vendor for posting a parody video that went viral.\n\nThere is little room for dissent against one-party rule in Vietnam, with critical voices subject to intimidation, harassment and travel restrictions.\n\nbur/srg/ah/smw\n\nMore from this section\n\nNational Nonprofit Petco Love Invests in Sacramento SPCA to Save and Improve the Lives of Pets in the
