He was 80.\n\nState media, citing information from Trong's medical team, said he died in the early afternoon on Friday \"after a period of illness\".\n\nIt said he died \"due to old age and serious illness\", without elaborating.\n\nVietnam's President To Lam took over Trong's duties on Thursday when the party announced aging leader needed to focus on medical treatment.\n\nThough Vietnam officially has no paramount ruler, the Soviet-educated Trong as party general secretary was the most powerful figure in the Communist-ruled nation and had been in the post since 2011.\n\nIn 2021 Trong secured a third term after a rule limiting holders to two terms as party boss was waived, demonstrating his strength and significant political clout in a party that has ruled Vietnam for nearly half a century.\n\nBut in recent months, he appeared fragile in public events and missed several top-level meetings.\n\nThe party will need to decide whether Lam will be acting party general secretary until the current term for the post expires after the next Congress in 2026, or whether it will elect a new candidate earlier from within its ranks.\n\nMarxist-Leninist ideologue Trong in 2017 unleashed what many see as a China-style crackdown on corruption, known as \"blazing furnace\", under which hundreds of officials were investigated for graft and many forced to quit, including cabinet ministers, a parliament chairman and two state presidents.\n\nLam, a former chief of the powerful internal security agency, was a key figure and beneficiary of that campaign and was elected president in May after his predecessor resigned amid accusations of unspecified wrongdoing.\n\n(This story has been corrected to say that Trong died early afternoon, not early morning, in paragraph party", "body": "Vietnamese leader Nguyen Phu Trong died on Friday aged 80 'after a period of illness', the ruling Communist Party said\n\nVietnamese leader Nguyen Phu Trong died on Friday aged 80 \"after a period of illness\", the ruling Communist Party said.\n\nThe announcement came a day after the party that Trong led said he would hand over power to focus on receiving medical treatment for an undisclosed medical condition.\n\nOn Friday, state media announced Trong had passed away in the afternoon at a military hospital \"due to old age and serious illness.\"\n\n\"There will be a special statement on the organisation of the funeral at the national level,\" state media added.\n\nTrong's responsibilities have been handed to the country's largely ceremonial president, To Lam, a powerful former public security minister long seen as jockeying for the top job.\n\n\"The Politburo calls on the entire party, people and army to have absolute trust in the party's leadership and state management,\" it said Thursday.\n\nThe country's communist regime, which is in the midst of a complete overhaul, has undergone a series of upheavals in recent months, with ministers, business leaders and two presidents all falling from grace as part of a vast anti-corruption campaign.\n\nLam was voted in as president in May by Vietnam's rubber-stamp parliament after his predecessor was forced to resign as part of the anti-graft drive.\n\nAnalysts said at the time that Lam, who was deputy head of the steering committee on anti-corruption matters, had weaponised investigations to take down his political rivals.\n\nHeaded by the party general secretary, Vietnam's leadership structure gives the president the second-most authority, and also includes the prime minister and the head of the National Assembly.\n\nTrong's poor health had fuelled widespread speculation that he would not be able to stay in power until the 2026 party congress, which is expected to appoint a successor.\n\nIn office since 2011, Trong enjoyed remarkable longevity in office, during a mandate that rights groups say has coincided with increasing authoritarianism.\n\nKnown for being a technocrat and on good {"uri": "8233915493", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:22:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:22:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:22:12Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7843137383460999, "url": "https://www.pbs.org/newshour/world/vietnam-communist-party-head-nguyen-phu-trong-countrys-most-powerful-leader-dies-at-age-80", "title": "Vietnam Communist Party head Nguyen Phu Trong, country's most powerful leader, dies at age 80", "body": "HANOI, Vietnam (AP) -- Nguyen Phu Trong, general secretary of Vietnam's ruling Communist Party and the country's most powerful politician, has died following months of ill health, official media said Friday. He was 80.\n\n\"General Secretary of the Central Committee of the Party Nguyen Phu Trong passed away at 13:38 on July 19, 2024, at the 108 Central Military Hospital due to old age and serious illness,\" the Nhan Dan newspaper said.\n\nOfficial media said a state funeral would be held.\n\nWATCH: The significance of Biden's trip to Vietnam in the face of China's growing influence\n\nTrong had dominated Vietnamese politics since 2011, when he was elected party chief. During his tenure, he worked to consolidate the Communist Party's power in Vietnam's single-party political system. In the decade before he took the top role in Vietnamese politics, the balance of power had shifted more toward the governmental wing led by then-Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung.\n\nBorn in 1944 in Hanoi, Trong was a Marxist-Leninist ideologue who earned a degree in philosophy before becoming a member of the Communist Party at the age of 22. He viewed corruption as the single gravest threat in maintaining the party's legitimacy.\n\n\"A country without discipline would be chaotic and unstable,\" Trong said in 2016 after being reelected to the party's helm. Officially, Vietnam has no top leader, but the Communist Party chief is traditionally seen as the most powerful.\n\nHe launched a sweeping anti-corruption campaign known as the \"blazing furnace\" that singed both business and political elites. Since 2016, thousands of party officials have been disciplined. They included former presidents Nguyen Xuan Phuc and Vo Van Thuong and the former head of parliament, Vuong Dinh Hue. In all, eight members of the powerful Politburo were ousted on corruption allegations, compared to none between 1986 and 2016.\n\nTrong studied in the Soviet Union from 1981 to 1983, and there was speculation that under his leadership, Vietnam would move closer to Russia and China. However, the Southeast Asian nation followed a pragmatic policy of \"bamboo diplomacy,\" a phrase he coined that referred to the plant's flexibility, bending but not breaking in the shifting headwinds of geopolitics.\n\nVietnam maintained its traditional ties with its much larger neighbor, China, dispute differences over sovereignty in the South China Sea. But it also drew closer to the United States, elevating its ties with its former Vietnam War foe to its highest diplomatic status, a comprehensive strategic partnership.\n\nTrong's legacy is mixed, with the unintended consequence of the anti-graft campaign being an erosion of institutions within the Communist Party, said Nguyen Khac Giang, a visiting fellow in the Vietnam Studies Program at Singapore's ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute. The party institutions were the bedrock ensuring that a balance of power remained among its different factions, he said.\n\n\"Vietnam has become more and more like China, where institutions and norms doesn't really matter as much as personal power,\" Giang said.\n\nVietanamese President To Lam was appointed the party caretaker on July 18 while Trong received treatment for his ill health. As Vietnam's top security official, Lam had led the anti-graft campaign until becoming president in May, when his predecessor resigned after being caught up in it.\n\nREAD MORE: Putin signs deals with Vietnam in effort to bolster ties in Asia to offset Moscow's growing isolation\n\nThe party's Politburo asked Lam to \"preside over the work of the Party Central Committee, the Politburo, and the Secretariat,\" according to a statement from its central office which was the first official confirmation of Trong's poor health.\n\nRumors about his health have swirled in Vietnamese politics since he was first hospitalized in 2019, and more recently when he appeared extremely frail while meeting visiting Russian President Vladmir Putin.\n\nTrong' death leaves behind a yawning political vacuum in Vietnam. Although Lam is widely viewed as the likely next party chief, Giang predicted \"a very uncertain time\" in Vietnamese politics because the norms and institutions governing the country are \"very shaky.\"\n\n\"Now it isn't only about the rules or norms, but it is also about who holds the most power,\" Giang said.\n\nThe central committee of the Chinese Communist Party sent its condolences to its Vietnamese counterpart and \"deeply mourned\" Trong's death, the state-run Xinhua news agency reported Friday.", "source": {"uri": "pbs.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "PBS.org"}, "authors": "label": {"eng": "Nh\u00e2n D\u00e2n"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Nguy\u1ec5n_T\u1ea5n_D\u0169ng", "type": "person", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Nguy\u1ec5n T\u1ea5n D\u0169ng"}}, {"uri": "8231662774", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "11:37:51", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T11:37:51Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T11:27:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/ap/article-13647373/Vietnams-President-To-Lam-caretaker-Communist-Party-chief-Trong-focuses-health.html", "title": "Vietnam's President To Lam becomes caretaker of Communist Party...", "body": "HANOI, Vietnam (AP) - Vietnamese President To Lam on Thursday became the caretaker of the Communist Party because of party chief Nguyen Phu Trong's poor health, the party said in a statement.\n\nNguyen Phu Trong, who was elected to a third term as general secretary in 2021, has dominated Vietnamese politics since he became party chief in 2011. He is an ideologue who views corruption as the gravest threat facing the party.\n\nAs Vietnam\u00b4s top security official, Lam led Trong\u00b4s sweeping anti-graft campaign until May, when he became president following the resignation of his predecessor, who stood down after being caught by the campaign.\n\nLam is widely viewed as the top candidate to replace Trong when the latter's term ends in 2026. He spent over four decades in the Ministry of Public Security before becoming the minister in 2016 and had been a key figure in the execution of anti-corruption measures.\n\nThe party's powerful Politburo has now asked Lam to \"preside over the work of the Party Central Committee, the Politburo, and the Secretariat,\" according to a statement from the party\u00b4s central office.\n\nThe statement also confirmed Trong's ill health which had long been rumored but didn't give any further details.\n\nFILE - Vietnamese President To Lam speaks during a press briefing with Russian President Vladimir Putin at the Presidential Palace in Hanoi, Vietnam, on June 20, 2024. To Lam on Thursday July 18, 2024 became the caretaker of the Communist Party because of party chief Nguyen Phu Trong's poor health, the party said in a statement. {"uri": "8233722597", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "14:59:58", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T14:59:58Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T14:59:22Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.firstpost.com/explainers/who-was-nguyen-phu-trong-vietnams-most-influential-leader-who-pioneered-bamboo-diplomacy-13794909.html", "title": "Who was Nguyen Phu Trong, Vietnam's most influential leader who pioneered 'Bamboo diplomacy'", "body": "Vietnam's then-President Nguyen Phu Trong speaks at a news conference after he is re-elected as Communist Party's General Secretary for the 3rd term after the closing ceremony of 13th national congress of the ruling communist party in Hanoi, Vietnam February 1, 2021. File Image/Reuters\n\nNguyen Phu Trong, the influential General Secretary of Vietnam's ruling Communist Party, passed away on July 19, at the age of 80. His death marks the end of an era for Vietnam, where he held the most powerful position for over 13 years.\n\nDuring his tenure, Trong oversaw rapid economic growth, launched a rigourous anti-corruption campaign, and steered the country's foreign policy towards a pragmatic and balanced approach known as \"Bamboo Diplomacy.\"\n\nBorn in Hanoi in 1944, Trong was a staunch Marxist-Leninist who earned a degree in philosophy before joining the Communist Party at the age of 22. He furthered his education in the Soviet Union, which shaped much of his ideological and political outlook. Despite his ideological leanings, Trong was known for nurturing relations with both the United States and China, reflecting his flexible and strategic approach to foreign policy.\n\nTrong had also served as president of Vietnam from 2018 to 2021.\n\nA look at Trong's rise to power\n\nTrong ascended to the role of General Secretary of the Communist Party in 2011, a position he held until his death. Prior to this, he served as the Party committee secretary of Hanoi and as the Chairman of the National Assembly from 2006 to 2011.\n\nHis rise to power was marked by his ability to consolidate the Communist Party's influence, particularly at a time when the governmental wing, led by then-Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung, was gaining prominence.\n\nIn 2021, he secured an unprecedented third term as General Secretary after the party waived the two-term limit, underscoring his significant political clout. However, his later years in office were marked by declining health, leading to his hospitalisation in 2019 and subsequent frailty at public events.\n\nTrong's 'blazing furnace'\n\nTrong is perhaps best known for his aggressive anti-corruption campaign, dubbed the \"blazing furnace.\" Launched in 2017, this campaign targeted both business and political elites, resulting in the investigation and resignation of hundreds of officials, including cabinet ministers, a parliament chairman, and two state presidents (Nguyen Xuan Phuc and Vo Van Thuong).\n\n\"A country without discipline would be chaotic and unstable,\" Trong stated in 2016, highlighting his belief in maintaining the party's legitimacy through strict discipline.\n\nThe campaign, while praised for its rigour, also had unintended consequences. Nguyen Khac Giang of the ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute also wrote in Fulcrum that the crackdown eroded the institutional balance within the Communist Party, shifting the dynamics towards personal power rather than established norms.\n\nTrong's 'Bamboo Diplomacy'\n\nTrong's foreign policy strategy, coined as \"Bamboo Diplomacy,\" symbolised Vietnam's resilience and adaptability in the complex geopolitical landscape of Southeast Asia. This approach allowed Vietnam to maintain robust economic and political relations with both the United States and China, despite the rising tensions between the two superpowers.\n\n\"Vietnam's diplomacy is described as soft and wise, yet persistent and resolute,\" Trong explained during the National Congress on External Relations in 2021. \"It is characterised by being flexible and creative in the face of all struggles and challenges that stand in the way of national independence and people's happiness.\"\n\nNotably, Trong was invited to India on a four-day State visit in November 2013 when he was received by then-Prime Minister Manmohan Singh in New Delhi. Then President Ram Nath Kovind visited Hanoi and met Trong in 2018 who was then president of the Southeast Asian nation. Prime Minister Narendra Modi had also held an audience with Trong in 2016 during his visit to Hanoi.\n\nUnder Trong's leadership, Vietnam elevated its ties with the United States to the highest diplomatic status, a comprehensive strategic partnership. He hosted both US President Joe Biden and China's leader Xi Jinping in Hanoi, showcasing Vietnam's balanced approach. The US embassy in Vietnam lauded him as a \"visionary leader who for decades served as a bridge between Vietnam and the United States of America.\"\n\nVietnam's economy under Trong\n\nVietnam's economy flourished under Trong's leadership. By 2022, the country's total exports reached $371.3 billion, with imports amounting to $358.9 billion, reflecting a 9.1 per cent increase compared to the previous year. High-tech items like phones and computers made up approximately $170 billion of these exports.\n\nThis economic boom attracted multinational giants such as Samsung, Intel, Canon, and Foxconn to establish large factories in Vietnam.\n\nTrong's pragmatic approach also involved balancing relations between major powers. In 2023, when the USS Ronald Reagan visited Vietnam, Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh was in China, underscoring Vietnam's diplomatic balancing act. These events highlighted Vietnam's efforts to maintain political trust and enhance strategic cooperation with both the United States and China.\n\nWho will replace Trong?\n\nFollowing Trong's death, his duties were temporarily assigned to Vietnamese President To Lam, a prominent figure in the party and a key player in the anti-corruption campaign. Lam, who became president in May 2024, is seen as a likely successor to Trong. However, his potential consolidation of power raises concerns about increased autocracy and a potential crackdown on civil liberties.\n\nVietnam's leadership structure consists of four key positions: the Communist Party general secretary, the president, the prime minister, and the head of the National Assembly, the four bureaucratic positions have been informally dubbed the \"four pillars\" in regard to leadership and decision-making in the country.\n\nPeter Mumford of the Eurasia Group noted that Lam's leadership could \"moderate political instability and factional infighting,\" which might benefit economic growth, reported Reuters. However, some analysts fear that Vietnam might drift towards a more China-style rule if Lam amasses unchecked power.\n\nIn the wake of Trong's death, Vietnam observed a period of national mourning, with public events cancelled and state-run websites displaying black and white banners. State broadcasters aired documentaries celebrating his life and leadership.\n\nAlso Read: Who is To Lam, Vietnam's top cop now elected president?\n\nNguyen Phu Trong leaves behind a mixed legacy marked by economic achievements, a rigourous anti-corruption drive, and a vision of \"Bamboo Diplomacy\" which will continue to influence Vietnam's strategic decisions in the years to come.", "news/Politics", "label": "news/Politics", "wgt": 99}], "image": "https://images.firstpost.com/uploads/2024/07/Nguyen-Phu-Trong-Vietnam-1-Reuters-2024-07-30952d098c97fbbcd16ab9d12f1c8f27.jpg?im=FitAndFill=(1200,675)", "originalArticle": null, "storyUri": "eng-9743079", "eventUri": "eng-9743079", "location": null, "extractedDates": [{"amb": false, "imp": true, "date": "2024-07-19", "textStart": 392, "textEnd": 399}, {"amb": false, "date": "2013-11-", "textStart": 3692, "textEnd": 3705}], "sentiment": 0.2627450980392156, "wgt": 199, "relevance": 1}
{"uri": "2024-07-427267526", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "14:30:45", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T14:30:45Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T13:55:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.eagletribune.com/region/vietnam-s-most-powerful-leader-party-chief-trong-dies/article_10f026ed-69e2-5ac9-81c1-b0eb10cdfed7.html", "title": "Vietnam's most powerful leader, party chief Trong, dies", "body": "John Boudreau, Nguyen Dieu Tu Uyen and Nguyen Xuan Quynh - Bloomberg News (TNS)\n\nNguyen Phu Trong, Vietnam's Communist Party chief and the country's most powerful official, has died, according a government statement.\n\nTrong, 80, was the general secretary of the party from 2011 until his death. He also served as the nation's president from 2018 to 2021.\n\nTrong died after a period of illness at 1:38 p.m. Friday at a military hospital in Hanoi, the statement said. The leader died \"due to old age and serious illness, despite getting dedicated treatment\" from his doctors and the nation's leading medical experts, the government said.\n\nThe government canceled a series of music performances across the country, according to local media reports. The government's website was turned into a shade of grey after the announcement of Trong's death.\n\nArguably the country's most influential leader since Ho Chi Minh, Trong oversaw a vast economic expansion including deeper ties with both China and a former foe, the U.S. Under his watch, Vietnam unleashed a sweeping campaign to root out corruption that has ensnared hundreds of officials and business leaders.\n\nThe politburo on Thursday tapped President To Lam to become the interim leader due to Trong's health emergency.\n\nTrong was elected as general secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam in 2011 and reelected to the position in 2016 and 2021. He also become president in 2018, a break from party tradition following the death of then-President Tran Dai Quang. Trong relinquished the presidency in 2021, but his election that year to a rare third term as general secretary made him the longest-serving party leader since Le Duan, who held the post from 1960 until his death in 1986.\n\nTrong headed the nation's central steering committee to tackle corruption since 2013. In recent years, he likened his anti-graft campaign to a \"blazing furnace,\" one that since at least 2021 has caught scores of government officials and business executives alike in its flames.\n\nThe crackdown has been portrayed as part of Vietnam's attempts to bolster its appeal as a destination for foreign investment in the midst of a heated competition between the U.S. and China, and to ensure the party's legitimacy in the face of wide-ranging scandals. However, it also led to widespread fear among bureaucrats, causing them to foot-drag on decision-making and approval of legal documents needed for new development and other business-related activities.\n\n\"Nguyen Phu Trong is undoubtedly the most influential Vietnamese politician of the 21st century,\" Linh Nguyen, lead analyst for Vietnam at Control Risks. \"He leaves a legacy of a party's unquestioned power fully restored and an unprecedented anti-corruption campaign that has cracked down hundreds corrupted senior politicians.\"\n\nTrong was a strong proponent of opening the once-isolated nation to foreign investment. Vietnam transformed into one of the most trade-dependent economies in the world with the signing of numerous free-trade agreements. As of end 2023, the value of Vietnam's exports roughly equaled the size of its economy, with former foe U.S. now its largest export market.\n\nIn 2015, Trong became the first party chief to visit the U.S. when he met former President Barack Obama at the White House. On that occasion, Obama said the \"difficult history\" between the US and Vietnam was being replaced by a relationship based on mutual economic and security interests in a region that was growing wary of China's rise. Trong said the US and Vietnam had managed to \"rise above the past\" to become friends.\n\nPossible successors\n\nThe selection of a leader is a highly secretive process and analysts expect the vacancy at the top could spark fierce competition within the politburo and the central executive committee.\n\nLam is in a strong position to become the next party chief, but it's not guaranteed. The former security minister and Trong's long-time anti-corruption crusader helped lift Vietnam's ranking in Transparency International's corruption perceptions index to 83 last year from 113 in 2016.\n\nTrong was born in Hanoi on April 14, 1944. His official biography says he came from a \"poor peasant\" family, according to state-owned Vietnam News.\n\nHe earned a bachelor's degree in philology, the study of language and literature, at Vietnam National University in 1967, according to the government's website. He had been interested in folk literature from a young age, according to a biography posted to the website of the university, which also displayed one of his first published works, a 1967 review of folk poetry, Reuters reported in 2021.\n\nHealth concerns\n\nTrong defended his Ph.D. thesis at the Party Building Department of the Academy of Social Sciences of the former Soviet Union in 1983. He took a postgraduate course in economics and politics at the Ho Chi Minh National Academy of Politics from 1973 to 1976.\n\nWith his prior experience as Hanoi's party secretary and chairman of the National Assembly, Trong was chosen as a compromise candidate for the general secretary position in 2011, said Le Hong Hiep, a former foreign ministry official who is now a senior fellow at the Vietnam Studies Program of ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute in Singapore.\n\nDuring a 2016 power struggle with Nguyen Tan Dung, Trong outmaneuvered the then prime minister to capture his second term as party chief, Hiep said. \"Beneath his grandfatherly appearance, Trong proved to be a determined and skilled politician.\"\n\nIn 2021, he was chosen for a third term as general secretary reportedly because the party could not reach a consensus on his successor.\n\nTrong's waning health was the topic of speculation for years. He appeared concerned about taking on the presidency in 2018, citing his \"worrisome\" old age and weakening health during an acceptance speech to the National Assembly.\n\nAfter being reelected party chief in 2021, he also said he would have preferred to retire because \"I'm old and not in good health.\" At the time, he failed to get a preferred candidate to replace him during the party reshuffle, forcing him to stay on as party chief.\n\nHe was hospitalized early January this year over an unspecified illness.\n\n-------\n\n(With assistance from Cecilia Yap, Philip J. Heijmans and Linh Vu Nguyen.)\n\n\u00a92024 Bloomberg L.P. Visit bloomberg.com. {"uri": "8233767603", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "15:30:11", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T15:30:11Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T15:29:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7803921699523926, "url": "https://www.news18.com/world/vietnams-top-leader-nguyen-phu-trong-dies-at-80-after-long-rule-pm-modi-extends-condolences-8972010.html", "title": "Vietnam's Top Leader Nguyen Phu Trong Dies At 80 After Long Rule; PM Modi Extends Condolences - News18", "body": "Vietnam's ruling Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong died on Friday after holding the country's most powerful position for 13 years during which he oversaw fast economic growth, a years-long anti-graft crackdown and a pragmatic foreign policy. He was 80.\n\nTrong's duties have been temporarily assigned to President To Lam, a rising star within the party who could further consolidate his powers if he is allowed to keep the two roles.\n\nPrime Minister Narendra Modi expressed condolences on the death of the Vietnamese leader.\n\n\"Saddened by the news of the passing away of the Vietnamese leader, General Secretary H.E. Nguyen Phu Trong. We pay our respects to the departed leader. Extend our deepest condolences and stand in solidarity with the people and leadership of Vietnam in this hour of grief,\" PM Modi said in an X post.\n\nTrong died in the early afternoon \"due to old age and serious illness\", the Communist Party said in a statement on its website, without elaborating further on the nature of the illness.\n\nThe statement cited information from Trong's medical team, saying he died \"after a period of illness, despite being wholeheartedly treated by the Party, the State, a collective of professors, doctors, leading medical experts\".\n\nLam had taken over Trong's duties on Thursday as the party chief was ailing. The party will now need to decide whether Lam will be formally appointed as acting party chief until the current term for the post expires in 2026, or whether it will elect a new head before then from within its ranks.\n\nAlthough Vietnam officially has no paramount ruler, Trong was the country's most powerful figure as party general secretary and had been in the post since 2011.\n\nHe secured a third term in 2021 after a rule limiting holders to two terms as party boss was waived, demonstrating his strength and significant political clout in a party that has ruled unified Vietnam for nearly half a century.\n\nBut in recent months, he appeared fragile in public events and missed several top-level meetings.\n\nA consolidation of power under Lam was seen by some business people and analysts as potentially positive to speed up decision-making in the Southeast Asian nation, which is home to large factories of top multinationals, including Samsung, Intel, Canon and Apple's top supplier Foxconn.\n\nA clear shift to Lam's leadership \"could moderate political instability and factional infighting, at least in the short term,\" said Peter Mumford, an expert on Southeast Asia at the Eurasia Group, noting that would be beneficial to economic growth.\n\nBut some diplomats and activists saw also risks of a crackdown on civil liberties and a drift toward more autocratic, China-style rule, if Lam were allowed to concentrate more unchecked powers in his hands, in a break with the party's tradition of collegial decision-making.\n\nAfter Trong's death was announced, public events were cancelled across the country until July 25 while state-run websites had their banners turned black and white.\n\nState broadcasters ran a documentary about Trong titled: \"General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong: a steadfast, intellectual, exemplary leader\".\n\nBars in the capital, Hanoi, declined to serve drinks or play music on Friday evening. Several Vietnamese Facebook users changed their profile picture into a national mourning flag.\n\nTrong was educated in the Soviet Union and was regarded as a Marxist-Leninist ideologue, but he nonetheless nurtured ties with the United States.\n\nIn 2017 he unleashed what many saw as a China-style crackdown on corruption, known as \"blazing furnace\", under which hundreds of officials were investigated for graft and many forced to quit, including cabinet ministers, a parliament chairman and two state presidents.\n\nThe operation had a chilling effect on investment.\n\nLam, a former chief of the powerful internal security agency, has been a key player in that campaign and was elected president in May after his predecessor resigned amid accusations of unspecified wrongdoing.\n\nTrong hosted both U.S. President Joe Biden and China's leader Xi Jinping in Hanoi last year, boosting relations with both countries despite increasing tensions between the U.S. and China.\n\nThe U.S. embassy in Vietnam said in a statement Trong was a \"visionary leader who for decades served as a bridge between Vietnam and the United States of America\", and praised him for being the first Vietnamese party leader to visit the United States.\n\nChina's Communist Party also sent a message of condolence to Vietnam, calling him a \"staunch Marxist\" and \"a good comrade, brother and friend,\" state media reported.", "source": {"uri": "news18.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "News18"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8233661426", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "14:17:41", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T14:17:41Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T14:16:50Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://ca.news.yahoo.com/vietnam-communist-leader-dies-aged-140544306.html", "title": "Vietnam's Communist leader dies aged 80 creating vast power vacuum", "body": "Nguyen Phu Trong, the general secretary of Vietnam's ruling Communist party and the country's most powerful politician, has died aged 80, creating a power vacuum.\n\nTrong died early on Friday afternoon \"after a period of illness\", according to his medical team, state media reported.\n\nTrong held Vietnam's most powerful position, general-secretary of Vietnam's ruling Communist party, since 2011, one of the longest-serving leaders in decades. He also served as president from 2018 to 2021.\n\nDuring his time in office, he oversaw a period of rapid economic growth as well as a balancing of ties with China and Vietnam's former foe, the US. Trong was known for his \"blazing furnace\" anti-corruption drive, under which even senior political figures, including former presidents, were forced to resign.\n\nThere had been speculation about Trong's health for months, fuelled by his absences from recent meetings.\n\n\"General secretary of the Central Committee of the Party, Nguyen Phu Trong, passed away at 13:38 on 19 July 2024, at the 108 Central Military hospital due to old age and serious illness,\" the Nhan Dan newspaper said.\n\nOn Thursday, it was announced he would step back from his role as head of the Communist party, due to unspecified health concerns, with president To Lam instead taking over his duties. Trong was awarded the Gold Star medal, the country's highest honour for public officials, on the same day.\n\nTrong will be remembered for his anti-corruption campaigns, which were unprecedented in the history of the party. Since 2016, more than 139,000 party members have been punished for corruption - a crackdown so vast it was blamed for negative impacts on the economy, with officials reluctant to sign off approvals, fearful of being accused of wrongdoing.\n\nRelated: Vietnam loses its second president in two years amid concerns for political stability\n\nIn pursuing such crackdowns, he \"consolidated an unrivalled level of power within the political system,\" said Nguyen Khac Giang, a visiting fellow at the Vietnam studies programme of the ISEAS - Yusof Ishak Institute in Singapore.\n\nAny plans that he had for an orderly succession transition had gone unrealised, he added, and his death risks creating a power vacuum.\n\nGiang added: \"I think this will lead [to] a very difficult time for Vietnam, for the political allies to negotiate among themselves who will assume the position of Nguyen Phu Trong. That might lead to a succession crisis where different factions would not agree.\"\n\nGiven Trong's power and popularity, analysts say any successor is unlikely to deviate from his policies in relation to the economy, foreign policy, or the lack of tolerance for government critics.\n\nThere are now more than 160 people held in prison for peacefully exercising their civil and political rights, according to Human Rights Watch.\n\nThe courts convicted at least 28 rights campaigners and sentenced them to long prison terms during the first 10 months of 2023, the group said.\n\nIn his foreign policy, Trong pursued a so-called \"bamboo diplomacy\" - which 'sways with the winds' and avoids picking sides in international disputes - including in relation to the rivalry between the US and China.\n\nIn 2015, he became the first general secretary of the Communist party to pay an official visit to the US, where he met with the former president Barack Obama.\n\nLast year Trong hosted the US president, Joe Biden, and upgraded ties with Washington, as well as with Australia and Japan. China's president, Xi Jinping, also made a state visit three months later.\n\nChina's Communist party central committee said the Chinese people had lost a \"good comrade, brother and friend\", Chinese state media reported.", "source": {"uri": "ca.news.yahoo.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Yahoo"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-427269468", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "14:32:35", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T14:32:35Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T00:00:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://m.arcamax.com/currentnews/newsheadlines/s-3334980", "title": "Vietnam's most powerful leader, party chief Trong, dies", "body": "Nguyen Phu Trong, Vietnam's Communist Party chief and the country's most powerful official, has died, according a government statement.\n\nTrong, 80, was the general secretary of the party from 2011 until his death. He also served as the nation's president from 2018 to 2021.\n\nTrong died after a period of illness at 1:38 p.m. Friday at a military hospital in Hanoi, the statement said. The leader died \"due to old age and serious illness, despite getting dedicated treatment\" from his doctors and the nation's leading medical experts, the government said.\n\nThe government canceled a series of music performances across the country, according to local media reports. The government's website was turned into a shade of grey after the announcement of Trong's death.\n\nArguably the country's most influential leader since Ho Chi Minh, Trong oversaw a vast economic expansion including deeper ties with both China and a former foe, the U.S. Under his watch, Vietnam unleashed a sweeping campaign to root out corruption that has ensnared hundreds of officials and business leaders.\n\nThe politburo on Thursday tapped President To Lam to become the interim leader due to Trong's health emergency.\n\nTrong was elected as general secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam in 2011 and reelected to the position in 2016 and 2021. He also become president in 2018, a break from party tradition following the death of then-President Tran Dai Quang. Trong relinquished the presidency in 2021, but his election that year to a rare third term as general secretary made him the longest-serving party leader since Le Duan, who held the post from 1960 until his death in 1986.\n\nTrong headed the nation's central steering committee to tackle corruption since 2013. In recent years, he likened his anti-graft campaign to a \"blazing furnace,\" one that since at least 2021 has caught scores of government officials and business executives alike in its flames.\n\nThe crackdown has been portrayed as part of Vietnam's attempts to bolster its appeal as a destination for foreign investment in the midst of a heated competition between the U.S. and China, and to ensure the party's legitimacy in the face of wide-ranging scandals. However, it also led to widespread fear among bureaucrats, causing them to foot-drag on decision-making and approval of legal documents needed for new development and other business-related activities.\n\n\"Nguyen Phu Trong is undoubtedly the most influential Vietnamese politician of the 21st century,\" Linh Nguyen, lead analyst for Vietnam at Control Risks. \"He leaves a legacy of a party's unquestioned power fully restored and an unprecedented anti-corruption campaign that has cracked down hundreds corrupted senior politicians.\"\n\nTrong was a strong proponent of opening the once-isolated nation to foreign investment. Vietnam transformed into one of the most trade-dependent economies in the world with the signing of numerous free-trade agreements. As of end 2023, the value of Vietnam's exports roughly equaled the size of its economy, with former foe U.S. now its largest export market.\n\nIn 2015, Trong became the first party chief to visit the U.S. when he met former President Barack Obama at the White House. On that occasion, Obama said the \"difficult history\" between the US and Vietnam was being replaced by a relationship based on mutual economic and security interests in a region that was growing wary of China's rise. Trong said the US and Vietnam had managed to \"rise above the past\" to become friends.\n\nPossible successors\n\nThe selection of a leader is a highly secretive process and analysts expect the vacancy at the top could spark fierce competition within the politburo and the central executive committee.\n\nLam is in a strong position to become the next party chief, but it's not guaranteed. The former security minister and Trong's long-time anti-corruption crusader helped lift Vietnam's ranking in Transparency International's corruption perceptions index to 83 last year from 113 in 2016.\n\nTrong was born in Hanoi on April 14, 1944. His official biography says he came from a \"poor peasant\" family, according to state-owned Vietnam News.\n\nHe earned a bachelor's degree in philology, the study of language and literature, at Vietnam National University in 1967, according to the government's website. He had been interested in folk literature from a young age, according to a biography posted to the website of the university, which also displayed one of his first published works, a 1967 review of folk poetry, Reuters reported in 2021.\n\nHealth concerns\n\nTrong defended his Ph.D. thesis at the Party Building Department of the Academy of Social Sciences of the former Soviet Union in 1983. He took a postgraduate course in economics and politics at the Ho Chi Minh National Academy of Politics from 1973 to 1976.\n\nWith his prior experience as Hanoi's party secretary and chairman of the National Assembly, Trong was chosen as a compromise candidate for the general secretary position in 2011, said Le Hong Hiep, a former foreign ministry official who is now a senior fellow at the Vietnam Studies Program of ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute in Singapore.\n\nDuring a 2016 power struggle with Nguyen Tan Dung, Trong outmaneuvered the then prime minister to capture his second term as party chief, Hiep said. \"Beneath his grandfatherly appearance, Trong proved to be a determined and skilled politician.\"\n\nIn 2021, he was chosen for a third term as general secretary reportedly because the party could not reach a consensus on his successor.\n\nTrong's waning health was the topic of speculation for years. He appeared concerned about taking on the presidency in 2018, citing his \"worrisome\" old age and weakening health during an acceptance speech to the National Assembly.\n\nAfter being reelected party chief in 2021, he also said he would have preferred to retire because \"I'm old and not in good health.\" At the time, he failed to get a preferred candidate to replace him during the party reshuffle, forcing him to stay on as party chief.\n\nHe was hospitalized early January this year over an unspecified illness.\n\n-------\n\n(With assistance from Cecilia Yap, Philip J. Heijmans and Linh Vu Nguyen.)", "source": {"uri": "m.arcamax.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "m.arcamax.com"}, "authors": [{"uri": "arcamax_publishing@m.arcamax.com", "name": "ArcaMax Publishing", {"uri": "8233940129", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:43:28", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:43:28Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:42:42Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7764706015586853, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-13652545/Vietnamese-leader-Nguyen-Phu-Trong-dead-80.html", "title": "Vietnamese leader Nguyen Phu Trong dead at 80", "body": "Vietnamese leader Nguyen Phu Trong has died aged 80 'after a period of illness', the ruling Communist Party said\n\nThe general secretary of Vietnam's Communist Party Nguyen Phu Trong -- considered the country's top leader -- died on Friday aged 80, his party said.\n\nIn a statement, it said Trong, who had led the party since 2011, died \"due to old age and serious illness\" at a military hospital in Hanoi.\n\nThe announcement came a day after the party announced Trong would hand the reins of power to the country's president and former public security minister To Lam, long seen as jockeying for the top job.\n\nAt the time, the party said Trong would be focusing on treatment for an undisclosed medical condition, the first time it had referenced longstanding speculation about the ageing leader's health.\n\nThere were no further details about Trong's illness on Friday, and the party said it would later make \"a special statement on the organisation of the funeral at the national level\".\n\nTrong is the first party general secretary to die in office since the death in 1986 of Le Duan, a brother-in-arms of Ho Chi Minh.\n\nHe is also the first leader to have held three consecutive mandates at the head of the party, after the liberalisation of the economy in 1986.\n\nUS President Joe Biden called Trong a \"champion of the deep ties\" between the American and Vietnamese people, and said both countries were more secure because of the bilateral friendship fostered by the late leader.\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin hailed Trong as a \"true friend\" of Russia.\n\nChina's communist party sent a message of condolences to its Vietnamese counterpart, Chinese state media said.\n\nVietnam's communist regime, which is in the midst of a complete overhaul, has undergone a series of upheavals in recent months, with ministers, business leaders and two presidents all falling from grace as part of a vast anti-corruption campaign.\n\nOn Thursday, when it was announced Trong was handing over his duties, the politburo called \"on the entire party, people and army to have absolute trust in the party's leadership and state management\".\n\nLam was voted in as president in May by Vietnam's rubber-stamp parliament after his predecessor was forced to resign as part of the anti-graft drive.\n\nAnalysts said at the time that Lam, who was deputy head of the steering committee on anti-corruption matters, had weaponised investigations to take down his political rivals.\n\n- 'Astonishing efficiency' -\n\nTrong's poor health had fuelled widespread speculation that he would not be able to stay in power until the 2026 party congress, which is expected to appoint a successor.\n\nHe enjoyed remarkable longevity in office, during a mandate that rights groups say has coincided with increasing authoritarianism.\n\nKnown for being a technocrat and on good terms with Beijing, he structured the party around himself, benefiting from a decade of economic growth that strengthened his legitimacy.\n\n\"He restructured and reorganised the party around him\" through his anti-corruption drive, said Benoit de Treglode, research director at the Institute for Strategic Research at France's military academy in Paris.\n\n\"Since 2011, he has cleaned up with astonishing efficiency.\"\n\nThe anti-corruption drive, which analysts say is also linked to political infighting, has swept through the party, police, armed forces and business community.\n\nMore than 3,500 people have been indicted since 2021, official figures show, while those sent to prison include a former health minister and two previous mayors of Hanoi.\n\nFollowing a scandal related to the Covid-19 pandemic last year, President Nguyen Xuan Phuc resigned and two deputy prime ministers were removed from their positions.\n\nMany other prominent officials working across a wide range of sectors, from environment and energy to healthcare and banking, are under investigation.\n\nBut the campaign has had unintended consequences. With many fearful of being caught in its crosshairs, everyday transactions within the business sector and the state apparatus have slowed.\n\nTrong would like to be remembered \"as a populist, someone very close to the people, who listens to the people\", said Linh Nguyen, lead analyst for Control Risks on Vietnam.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", "dataType": "news", "title": "Daily Mail {"uri": "8231519413", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "10:00:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T10:00:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T09:59:28Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/asia/southeast-asia/article/3270961/vietnams-president-lam-takes-over-party-chief-duties-trong-focuses-health", "title": "Vietnam's President Lam takes party chief duties as Trong focuses on health", "body": "President To Lam has taken over the duties of Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong who is focusing on an unspecified health treatment\n\nVietnam\u2019s President To Lam has taken over the duties of Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong, who is focusing on an unspecified health treatment, the party said on Thursday.\n\nThe extraordinary move comes after months of speculation that Trong\u2019s health was weakening. The party did not clarify what treatment he is receiving, and a spokesperson for the ministry of foreign affairs had no additional information to share when asked at a regular media briefing.\n\nLam, a former head of internal security, has been widely seen as a top candidate to replace Trong when his term ends in 2026. The party\u2019s powerful Politburo has tasked him with temporarily presiding over \u201cthe work of the Party Central Committee, the Politburo and the Secretariat,\u201d according to a statement from the party\u2019s central office.\n\n\u201cLooking at the current state, Lam has the highest chance to become the acting party chief until 2026,\u201d said Nguyen Khac Giang, expert on Vietnam at Singapore-based think tank ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute.\n\nFor Lam to be officially appointed as acting party chief, a new Politburo decision will be needed.\n\nIn its statement on Thursday, the Politburo called on the party, the army and the people \u201cto have absolute confidence in the leadership of the party\u201d.\n\nThough Vietnam officially has no paramount ruler, the party chief holds the most powerful position in the Communist-ruled nation. Trong, 80, has been in the post since 2011.Corruption crackdown\n\nTrong, a Marxist-Leninist ideologue, has since 2017 unleashed what many see as a China-style crackdown on corruption known as \u201cblazing furnace\u201d. But in recent months, he has appeared fragile in public events and missed several top-level meetings.\n\nIn a surprise move, the Politburo awarded Trong on Thursday the Gold Star medal, the country\u2019s highest honour for public officials.\n\nLam was elected president in May after several top leaders quit amid accusations of unspecified wrongdoing.\n\nLam, a key player in the crackdown, promised after his election to \u201cresolutely and persistently continue the fight against corruption\u201d, despite its negative impact on public investment.\n\n\u201cWhoever takes over from Trong to become the next party chief, it is essential to keep his anti-corruption campaign legacy to have the authority in front of other political elites, keep the system\u2019s stability and gain favour from others,\u201d said Giang.\n\nVietnam\u2019s main stock market edged up 0.5 per cent after the announcement.\n\nA Hanoi-based senior Western diplomat said he saw Lam\u2019s expanded powers as good for stability.\n\nBut the diplomat, who declined to be identified, added: \u201cWe\u2019ll need to see if this has an impact on economic, foreign and domestic policies and in which {"uri": "8233960741", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "18:02:44", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T18:02:44Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T18:01:25Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.ndtv.com/world-news/vietnamese-most-powerful-communist-party-leader-nguyen-phu-trong-dies-at-80-6143533", "title": "Vietnamese Most Powerful Communist Party Leader Nguyen Phu Trong Dies At 80", "body": "The announcement came a day after the party announced Nguyen Phu Trong would hand the reins of power to the country's president and former public security minister To Lam, long seen as jockeying for the top job.\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin hailed Nguyen Phu Trong as a \"true friend\" of Russia.\n\nThe general secretary of Vietnam's Communist Party Nguyen Phu Trong -- considered the country's top leader -- died on Friday aged 80, his party said.\n\nIn a statement, it said Trong, who had led the party since 2011, died \"due to old age and serious illness\" at a military hospital in Hanoi.\n\nThe announcement came a day after the party announced Trong would hand the reins of power to the country's president and former public security minister To Lam, long seen as jockeying for the top job.\n\nAt the time, the party said Trong would be focusing on treatment for an undisclosed medical condition, the first time it had referenced longstanding speculation about the ageing leader's health.\n\nThere were no further details about Trong's illness on Friday, and the party said it would later make \"a special statement on the organisation of the funeral at the national level\".\n\nTrong is the first party general secretary to die in office since the death in 1986 of Le Duan, a brother-in-arms of Ho Chi Minh.\n\nHe is also the first leader to have held three consecutive mandates at the head of the party, after the liberalisation of the economy in 1986.\n\nUS President Joe Biden called Trong a \"champion of the deep ties\" between the American and Vietnamese people, and said both countries were more secure because of the bilateral friendship fostered by the late leader.\n\nRussian President Vladimir Putin hailed Trong as a \"true friend\" of Russia.\n\nChina's communist party sent a message of condolences to its Vietnamese counterpart, Chinese state media said.\n\nVietnam's communist regime, which is in the midst of a complete overhaul, has undergone a series of upheavals in recent months, with ministers, business leaders and two presidents all falling from grace as part of a vast anti-corruption campaign.\n\nOn Thursday, when it was announced Trong was handing over his duties, the politburo called \"on the entire party, people and army to have absolute trust in the party's leadership and state management\".\n\nLam was voted in as president in May by Vietnam's rubber-stamp parliament after his predecessor was forced to resign as part of the anti-graft drive.\n\nAnalysts said at the time that Lam, who was deputy head of the steering committee on anti-corruption matters, had weaponised investigations to take down his political rivals.\n\n- 'Astonishing efficiency' -\n\nTrong's poor health had fuelled widespread speculation that he would not be able to stay in power until the 2026 party congress, which is expected to appoint a successor.\n\nHe enjoyed remarkable longevity in office, during a mandate that rights groups say has coincided with increasing authoritarianism.\n\nKnown for being a technocrat and on good terms with Beijing, he structured the party around himself, benefiting from a decade of economic growth that strengthened his legitimacy.\n\n\"He restructured and reorganised the party around him\" through his anti-corruption drive, said Benoit de Treglode, research director at the Institute for Strategic Research at France's military academy in Paris.\n\n\"Since 2011, he has cleaned up with astonishing efficiency.\"\n\nThe anti-corruption drive, which analysts say is also linked to political infighting, has swept through the party, police, armed forces and business community.\n\nMore than 3,500 people have been indicted since 2021, official figures show, while those sent to prison include a former health minister and two previous mayors of Hanoi.\n\nFollowing a scandal related to the Covid-19 pandemic last year, President Nguyen Xuan Phuc resigned and two deputy prime ministers were removed from their positions.\n\nMany other prominent officials working across a wide range of sectors, from environment and energy to healthcare and banking, are under investigation.\n\nBut the campaign has had unintended consequences. With many fearful of being caught in its crosshairs, everyday transactions within the business sector and the state apparatus have slowed.\n\nPromotedListen to the latest songs, only on JioSaavn.com\n\nTrong would like to be remembered \"as a populist, someone very close to the people, who listens to the people\", said Linh Nguyen, lead analyst for Control Risks on Vietnam.\n\n(Except for the headline, this story has not been edited by NDTV staff and is published from a syndicated feed.)", "source": {"uri": "ndtv.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "NDTV"}, {"uri": "8233903387", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:13:23", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:13:23Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:13:03Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.772549033164978, "url": "https://www.arcamax.com/currentnews/newsheadlines/s-3335133", "title": "Vietnam's most powerful leader, party chief Trong, dies", "body": "Nguyen Phu Trong, Vietnam's Communist Party chief and the country's most powerful official, has died, according a government statement.\n\nTrong, 80, was the general secretary of the party from 2011 until his death. He also served as the nation's president from 2018 to 2021.\n\nTrong died after a period of illness at 1:38 p.m. Friday at a military hospital in Hanoi, the statement said. The leader died \"due to old age and serious illness, despite getting dedicated treatment\" from his doctors and the nation's leading medical experts, the government said.\n\nThe government canceled a series of music performances across the country, according to local media reports. The government's website was turned into a shade of grey after the announcement of Trong's death.\n\nArguably the country's most influential leader since Ho Chi Minh, Trong oversaw a vast economic expansion including deeper ties with both China and a former foe, the U.S. Under his watch, Vietnam unleashed a sweeping campaign to root out corruption that has ensnared hundreds of officials and business leaders.\n\nThe politburo on Thursday tapped President To Lam to become the interim leader due to Trong's health emergency.\n\nTrong was elected as general secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam in 2011 and reelected to the position in 2016 and 2021. He also become president in 2018, a break from party tradition following the death of then-President Tran Dai Quang. Trong relinquished the presidency in 2021, but his election that year to a rare third term as general secretary made him the longest-serving party leader since Le Duan, who held the post from 1960 until his death in 1986.\n\nTrong headed the nation's central steering committee to tackle corruption since 2013. In recent years, he likened his anti-graft campaign to a \"blazing furnace,\" one that since at least 2021 has caught scores of government officials and business executives alike in its flames.\n\nThe crackdown has been portrayed as part of Vietnam's attempts to bolster its appeal as a destination for foreign investment in the midst of a heated competition between the U.S. and China, and to ensure the party's legitimacy in the face of wide-ranging scandals. However, it also led to widespread fear among bureaucrats, causing them to foot-drag on decision-making and approval of legal documents needed for new development and other business-related activities.\n\n\"Nguyen Phu Trong is undoubtedly the most influential Vietnamese politician of the 21st century,\" Linh Nguyen, lead analyst for Vietnam at Control Risks. \"He leaves a legacy of a party's unquestioned power fully restored and an unprecedented anti-corruption campaign that has cracked down hundreds corrupted senior politicians.\"\n\nTrong was a strong proponent of opening the once-isolated nation to foreign investment. Vietnam transformed into one of the most trade-dependent economies in the world with the signing of numerous free-trade agreements. As of end 2023, the value of Vietnam's exports roughly equaled the size of its economy, with former foe U.S. now its largest export market.\n\nIn 2015, Trong became the first party chief to visit the U.S. when he met former President Barack Obama at the White House. On that occasion, Obama said the \"difficult history\" between the U.S. and Vietnam was being replaced by a relationship based on mutual economic and security interests in a region that was growing wary of China's rise. Trong said the U.S. and Vietnam had managed to \"rise above the past\" to become friends.\n\nU.S. President Joe Biden echoed those sentiments on Friday, saying in a statement \"the people of Vietnam and the United States - and people across the Indo-Pacific region - enjoy greater security and opportunity today because of the friendship between our two countries,\" calling his 2015 visit \"historic.\"\n\nPossible successors\n\nThe selection of a leader is a highly secretive process and analysts expect the vacancy at the top could spark fierce competition within the politburo and the central executive committee.\n\nLam is in a strong position to become the next party chief, but it's not guaranteed. The former security minister and Trong's long-time anti-corruption crusader helped lift Vietnam's ranking in Transparency International's corruption perceptions index to 83 last year from 113 in 2016.\n\nTrong was born in Hanoi on April 14, 1944. His official biography says he came from a \"poor peasant\" family, according to state-owned Vietnam News.\n\nHe earned a bachelor's degree in philology, the study of language and literature, at Vietnam National University in 1967, according to the government's website. He had been interested in folk literature from a young age, according to a biography posted to the website of the university, which also displayed one of his first published works, a 1967 review of folk poetry, Reuters reported in 2021.\n\nHealth concerns\n\nTrong defended his Ph.D. thesis at the Party Building Department of the Academy of Social Sciences of the former Soviet Union in 1983. He took a postgraduate course in economics and politics at the Ho Chi Minh National Academy of Politics from 1973 to 1976.\n\nWith his prior experience as Hanoi's party secretary and chairman of the National Assembly, Trong was chosen as a compromise candidate for the general secretary position in 2011, said Le Hong Hiep, a former foreign ministry official who is now a senior fellow at the Vietnam Studies Program of ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute in Singapore.\n\nDuring a 2016 power struggle with Nguyen Tan Dung, Trong outmaneuvered the then prime minister to capture his second term as party chief, Hiep said. \"Beneath his grandfatherly appearance, Trong proved to be a determined and skilled politician.\"\n\nIn 2021, he was chosen for a third term as general secretary reportedly because the party could not reach a consensus on his successor.\n\nTrong's waning health was the topic of speculation for years. He appeared concerned about taking on the presidency in 2018, citing his \"worrisome\" old age and weakening health during an acceptance speech to the National Assembly.\n\nAfter being reelected party chief in 2021, he also said he would have preferred to retire because \"I'm old and not in good health.\" At the time, he failed to get a preferred candidate to replace him during the party reshuffle, forcing him to stay on as party chief.\n\nHe was hospitalized early January this year over an unspecified illness.\n\n-------\n\n(With assistance from Cecilia Yap, Philip J. Heijmans, Linh Vu Nguyen and Michelle Jamrisko.)", "source": {"uri": "arcamax.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "ArcaMax"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-425721188", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "08:49:52", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T08:49:52Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T04:34:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-07-18/vietnam-party-boss-trong-to-focus-on-medical-treatment-president-takes-over-duties", "title": "Vietnam President Lam Takes on Duties of Party Chief as Trong Focuses on Health", "body": "HANOI (Reuters) - Vietnam's President To Lam has taken over the duties of Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong who is focusing on an unspecified treatment for his health, the party said on Thursday.\n\nThe extraordinary move comes after months of speculation that Trong's health was weakening. The party did not clarify what treatment he is receiving.\n\nLam, a former head of internal security, has been widely seen as a top candidate to replace Trong when his term ends in 2026. The party's powerful Politburo has tasked him with presiding over \"the work of the Party Central Committee, the Politburo and the Secretariat,\" according to a statement from the party's central office.\n\nThough Vietnam officially has no paramount ruler, the party chief holds the most powerful position in the Communist-ruled nation. Trong, 80, has been in the post since 2011.\n\nTrong, a Marxist-Leninist ideologue, has since 2017 unleashed what many see as a China-style crackdown on corruption known as \"blazing furnace\". But in recent months, he has appeared fragile in public events and missed several top-level meetings.\n\nIn a surprise move, the Politburo awarded Trong on Thursday with the Gold Star medal, the country's highest honour for public officials.\n\nLam was elected president in May after several top leaders quit amid accusations of unspecified wrongdoing, part of the sweeping anti-graft campaign launched by Trong.\n\nLam, a key player in the crackdown, promised after his election to \"resolutely and persistently continue the fight against corruption\".\n\nVietnam's main stock market edged up 0.5% after the announcement.\n\nA Hanoi-based senior Western diplomat said he saw Lam's expanded powers as \"Good for stability.\"\n\nBut the diplomat, who declined to be identified, added: \"We'll need to see if this has an impact on economic, foreign and domestic policies and in which direction.\"\n\n(Reporting by Phuong Nguyen and Francesco Guarascio; Editing by Martin Petty and Edwina {"uri": "8233394970", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:22:14", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:22:14Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:20:57Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7686274647712708, "url": "https://www.devdiscourse.com/article/politics/3022920-vietnams-communist-party-leader-nguyen-phu-trong-passes-away-at-80", "title": "Vietnam's Communist Party Leader Nguyen Phu Trong Passes Away at 80 | Politics", "body": "Vietnam's Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong has died at 80 after a period of illness. He held the country's most powerful position for 13 years. President To Lam took over his duties on Thursday. Trong, known for his anti-corruption crackdown, appeared fragile recently and missed several meetings.\n\nVietnam's Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong, who held the country's most powerful position for 13 years, has died at the age of 80, according to state media on Friday. He succumbed to old age and a serious illness, passing away in the early afternoon.\n\nThe transition of power took place on Thursday when President To Lam assumed Trong's duties after the aging leader focused on medical treatment. Trong, a Soviet-educated figure, had been the most influential politician in Communist-ruled Vietnam since 2011. A rule limiting party bosses to two terms was waived for Trong in 2021, underscoring his immense political clout.\n\nIn recent months, Trong appeared frail at public events and missed key meetings. The party now faces the decision of whether to elect a new general secretary before the current term expires in 2026 or have Lam serve as the acting secretary. Known for launching a China-style anti-corruption campaign in 2017, Trong investigated numerous officials, leading to the resignation of top leaders, including cabinet ministers and state He is an ideologue who views corruption as the gravest threat facing the party.\n\nAs Vietnam's top security official, Lam led Trong's sweeping anti-graft campaign until May, when he became president following the resignation of his predecessor, who stood down after being caught by the campaign.\n\nLam is widely viewed as the top candidate to replace Trong when the latter's term ends in 2026. He spent over four decades in the Ministry of Public Security before becoming the minister in 2016 and had been a key figure in the execution of anti-corruption measures.\n\nThe party's powerful Politburo has now asked Lam to \"preside over the work of the Party Central Committee, the Politburo, and the Secretariat,\" according to a statement from the party's central office.\n\nThe statement {"uri": "8233496243", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "12:26:48", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T12:26:48Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T12:26:19Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.bangkokpost.com/world/2832358/vietnams-most-powerful-leader-party-chief-trong-dies", "title": "Vietnam\"s most powerful leader Nguyen Phu Trong dies", "body": "HANOI - Nguyen Phu Trong, Vietnam's Communist Party chief and the country's most powerful official, has died, according to a government statement.\n\nTrong, 80, was the general secretary of the party from 2011 until his death. He also served as the nation's president from 2018 to 2021.\n\nTrong died after a period of illness at 1.38pm on Friday at a military hospital in Hanoi, the statement said. The leader died \"due to old age and serious illness, despite getting dedicated treatment\" from his doctors and the nation's leading medical experts, the government said.\n\nThe government cancelled a series of music performances across the country, according to local media reports. The government's website was turned into a shade of grey after the announcement of Trong's death.\n\nArguably the country's most influential leader since Ho Chi Minh, Trong oversaw a vast economic expansion including deeper ties with both China and a former foe, the United States. Under his watch, Vietnam unleashed a sweeping campaign to root out corruption that has ensnared hundreds of officials and business leaders.\n\nThe politburo on Thursday tapped President To Lam to become the interim leader due to Trong's health emergency.\n\nTrong was elected as general secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam in 2011 and re-elected to the position in 2016 and 2021. He also become president in 2018, a break from party tradition following the death of then-President Tran Dai Quang. Trong relinquished the presidency in 2021, but his election that year to a rare third term as general secretary made him the longest-serving party leader since Le Duan, who held the post from 1960 until his death in 1986.\n\nTrong headed the nation's central steering committee to tackle corruption since 2013. In recent years, he likened his anti-graft campaign to a \"blazing furnace,\" one that since at least 2021 has caught scores of government officials and business executives alike in its flames.\n\nThe crackdown has been portrayed as part of Vietnam's attempts to bolster its appeal as a destination for foreign investment in the midst of a heated competition between the US and China, and to ensure the party's legitimacy in the face of wide-ranging scandals. However, it also led to widespread fear among bureaucrats, causing them to foot-drag on decision-making and approval of legal documents needed for new development and other business-related activities.\n\n\"Nguyen Phu Trong is undoubtedly the most influential Vietnamese politician of the 21st century,\" Linh Nguyen, lead analyst for Vietnam at Control Risks. \"He leaves a legacy of a party's unquestioned power fully restored and an unprecedented anti-corruption campaign that has cracked down hundreds corrupted senior politicians.\"\n\nTrong was a strong proponent of opening the once-isolated nation to foreign investment. Vietnam transformed into one of the most trade-dependent economies in the world with the signing of numerous free-trade agreements. As of end 2023, the value of Vietnam's exports roughly equaled the size of its economy, with former foe US now its largest export market.\n\nIn 2015, Trong became the first party chief to visit the US when he met former President Barack Obama at the White House. On that occasion, Obama said the \"difficult history\" between the US and Vietnam was being replaced by a relationship based on mutual economic and security interests in a region that was growing wary of China's rise. Trong said the US and Vietnam had managed to \"rise above the past\" to become friends.\n\nPossible successors\n\nThe selection of a leader is a highly secretive process, and analysts expect the vacancy at the top could spark fierce competition within the politburo and the central executive committee.\n\nLam is in a strong position to become the next party chief, but it's not guaranteed. The former security minister and Trong's long-time anti-corruption crusader helped lift Vietnam's ranking in Transparency International's corruption perceptions index to 83 last year from 113 in 2016.\n\nTrong was born in Hanoi on April 14, 1944. His official biography says he came from a \"poor peasant\" family, according to state-owned Vietnam News.\n\nHe earned a bachelor's degree in philology, the study of language and literature, at Vietnam National University in 1967, according to the government's website. He had been interested in folk literature from a young age, according to a biography posted to the website of the university, which also displayed one of his first published works, a 1967 review of folk poetry, Reuters reported in 2021.\n\nHealth concerns\n\nTrong defended his PhD thesis at the Party Building Department of the Academy of Social Sciences of the former Soviet Union in 1983. He took a postgraduate course in economics and politics at the Ho Chi Minh National Academy of Politics from 1973 to 1976.\n\nWith his prior experience as Hanoi's party secretary and chairman of the National Assembly, Trong was chosen as a compromise candidate for the general secretary position in 2011, said Le Hong Hiep, a former foreign ministry official who is now a senior fellow at the Vietnam Studies Program of ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute in Singapore.\n\nDuring a 2016 power struggle with Nguyen Tan Dung, Trong outmanoeuvred the then prime minister to capture his second term as party chief, Hiep said. \"Beneath his grandfatherly appearance, Trong proved to be a determined and skilled politician.\"\n\nIn 2021, he was chosen for a third term as general secretary reportedly because the party could not reach a consensus on his successor.\n\nTrong's waning health was the topic of speculation for years. He appeared concerned about taking on the presidency in 2018, citing his \"worrisome\" old age and weakening health during an acceptance speech to the National Assembly.\n\nAfter being re-elected party chief in 2021, he also said he would have preferred to retire because \"I'm old and not in good health.\" At the time, he failed to get a preferred candidate to replace him during the party reshuffle, forcing him to stay on as party chief.\n\nHe was hospitalised early January this year over an unspecified illness.", "source": {"uri": "bangkokpost.com", "dataType": "news", "title": {"uri": "8233987705", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "18:27:29", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T18:27:29Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T18:25:27Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.7607843279838562, "url": "https://www.cambodiantimes.com/news/274462541/vietnams-top-leader-trong-dies-at-80-after-long-rule", "title": "Vietnam's top leader Trong dies at 80 after long rule", "body": "HANOI, Vietnam - Vietnam's ruling Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong died on Friday after holding the country's most powerful position for 13 years during which he oversaw fast economic growth, a yearslong anti-graft crackdown and a pragmatic foreign policy. He was 80.\n\nTrong's duties have been temporarily assigned to President To Lam, a rising star within the party who could further consolidate his power if he is allowed to keep the two roles.\n\nTrong died in the early afternoon 'due to old age and serious illness,' the Communist Party said in a statement on its website, without elaborating further on the nature of the illness.\n\nThe statement cited information from Trong's medical team, saying he died 'after a period of illness, despite being wholeheartedly treated by the Party, the State, a collective of professors, doctors, leading medical experts.'\n\nLam had taken over Trong's duties on Thursday as the party chief was ailing. The party will now need to decide whether Lam will be formally appointed as acting party chief until the current term for the post expires in 2026, or whether it will elect a new head before then from within its ranks.\n\nAlthough Vietnam officially has no paramount ruler, Trong was the country's most powerful figure as party general secretary and had been in the post since 2011.\n\nHe secured a third term in 2021 after a rule limiting holders to two terms as party boss was waived, demonstrating his strength and significant political clout in a party that has ruled unified Vietnam for nearly half a century.\n\nBut in recent months, he appeared fragile in public events and missed several top-level meetings.\n\nWith Lam in power\n\nA consolidation of power under Lam was seen by some businesspeople and analysts as potentially positive to speed up decision-making in the Southeast Asian nation, which is home to large factories of top multinationals, including Samsung Intel, Canon and Apple's top supplier, Foxconn.\n\nA clear shift to Lam's leadership 'could moderate political instability and factional infighting, at least in the short term,' said Peter Mumford, an expert on Southeast Asia at the Eurasia Group, noting that it would be beneficial to economic growth.\n\nFILE - Vietnamese President To Lam speaks during a press briefing with Russian President Vladimir Putin, unseen, at the Presidential Palace in Hanoi, Vietnam, on June 20, 2024.\n\nBut some diplomats and activists saw risks of a crackdown on civil liberties and a drift toward more autocratic, China-style rule, if Lam were allowed to concentrate more unchecked powers in his hands, in a break with the party's tradition of collegial decision-making.\n\nAfter Trong's death was announced, public events were canceled across the country until July 25 while state-run websites had their banners turned black and white.\n\nState broadcasters ran a documentary about Trong titled: 'General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong: a steadfast, intellectual, exemplary leader.'\n\nBars in the capital, Hanoi, declined to serve drinks or play music on Friday evening. Several Vietnamese Facebook users changed their profile picture into a national mourning flag.\n\nMarxist-Leninist\n\nTrong was educated in the Soviet Union and was regarded as a Marxist-Leninist ideologue, but he nonetheless nurtured ties with the United States.\n\nIn 2017 he unleashed what many saw as a China-style crackdown on corruption, known as 'blazing furnace,' under which hundreds of officials were investigated for graft and many forced to quit, including cabinet ministers, a parliament chairman and two state presidents.\n\nThe operation had a chilling effect on investment.\n\nLam, a former chief of the powerful internal security agency, has been a key player in that campaign and was elected president in May after his predecessor resigned amid accusations of unspecified wrongdoing.\n\nTrong hosted U.S. President Joe Biden and Chinese leader Xi Jinping in Hanoi last year, boosting relations with both countries despite increasing tensions between the U.S. and China.\n\nThe U.S. embassy in Vietnam said in a statement Trong was a 'visionary leader who for decades served as a bridge between Vietnam and the United States of America,' and praised him for being the first Vietnamese party leader to visit the United States.\n\nChina's Communist Party also sent a message of condolence to Vietnam, calling him a 'staunch Marxist' and 'a good comrade, brother and friend,' state media reported.", "source": {"uri": "cambodiantimes.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "Cambodian Times"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri":
