{"uri": "2024-07-427496656", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "18:53:08", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T18:53:08Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T18:26:52Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6313725709915161, "url": "https://www.rfa.org/english/commentaries/vietnam-politics-nguyen-phu-trong-to-lam-07192024135846.html", "title": "Vietnamese Communist chief Nguyen Phu Trong leaves behind a weak, fractious party", "body": "His 'Blazing Furnace' anti-corruption drive tarnished the party's public image and allowed To Lam to seize power.\n\nOn July 19, Vietnamese state media reported that Nguyen Phu Trong, the long-serving general secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam, had died after an illness.\n\nThe report of Trong's passing at 80 came a day after the party brass had announced he had relinquished his powers to President To Lam due to his failing health. In a rushed announcement, he was awarded the Gold Star, the country's highest honor suggesting that the party did not want to have to do this posthumously.\n\nBorn on April 14, 1944, in Hanoi, Trong was a lifelong communist ideologue. He was educated at Hanoi National University, the H\u1ed3 Ch\u00ed Minh National Academy of Politics and Public Administration, and the Russian Academy of Social Sciences.\n\nHe spent several decades working for the party's ideological journal, T\u1ea1p ch\u00ed C\u1ed9ng S\u1ea3n (Communist Review), where he was editor-in-chief from 1991-1996.\n\nHe joined the Communist Party of Vietnam's (CPV) Central Committee in 1994, and was first elected to the Politburo at the 9th Party Congress in 1996.\n\nFrom 2000-2006, he served as the chairman of the Hanoi Party Committee. From 2001-2006, he concurrently headed the Central Committee's Theoretical Council, making him the top communist ideologue.\n\nHe held his first and only non-Party assignment from 2006-2011, as the chairman of the National Assembly.\n\nHe was elected general secretary at the 11th Party Congress in January 2011 and was re-elected at the 12th Congress in January 2016 with an age waiver, after ousting Prime Minister Nguyen Tan Dung, who had vied to be the party chief.\n\nTrong despised Dung, whose economic liberalization set the stage for today's growth, but also led to surging inequality and corruption.\n\nTrong became president when incumbent Tran Dai Quang passed away in September 2018. He ceded that role at the 13th Congress in January 2021.\n\nParty control and anti-corruption\n\nHe showed little interest in foreign affairs, although he met President Barack Obama in the Oval Office in 2018, traveled to Beijing in October 2022, and hosted President Joe Biden in September 2023, Xi Jinping in December 2023 and Vladimir Putin in June 2024.\n\nHaving served five terms on the Politburo, Trong had significant staying power in a system that has tried to implement a regular transition for leaders. But there were limits to his power in a system of collective leadership.\n\nTrong failed to get his protege Tran Quoc Vuong, who oversaw his anti-corruption campaign, elected as his successor at the 13th Congress.\n\nTrong, who was reported to have suffered a stroke in late 2020, stayed on as a compromise figure. It was a clear violation of the two-term norm that was established after the disastrous quarter-century-long reign of Le Duan, whose death in July 1986 set off the Doi Moi reform era.\n\nAt the time, it was widely expected that Trung would be a caretaker until an agreement on his successor could be reached, but he showed no inclination in stepping down, despite his advanced age and failing health. By late 2023, he was believed to be residing at the 108 Military Hospital, a special facility for top leaders.\n\nThere were two big themes to Trung's long tenure: re-asserting party control and anti-corruption.\n\nTrong was concerned that the Communist Party was being sidelined as the economy grew and became more complex, and the loci of decision making shifted to technocrats, such as Vu Duc Dam, a cosmopolitan former deputy prime minister.\n\nWhile Trong understood the importance of economic growth, he never believed in performance-based legitimacy. Like China's Xi Jinping, he believed that economic growth could never come at the expense of party control.\n\nUnder him, the Politburo, which traditionally tended to be a careful balance of competing institutional interests, sectoral and regional representation, became dangerously out of balance, demonstrating the regime's insecurity.\n\nAt the Central Committee's 9th Plenum in May 2024, four new members of the Politburo represented the party, not the state apparatus.\n\nCrushing civil society\n\nToday, five of the 16 members came out of the Vietnamese Ministry of Public Security, with three coming out of the army. That half the Politburo represents the security sector, with a palpable dearth of economic expertise, is evidence of the party's priorities for the nation of 100 million people.\n\nUnder Trong, the government stepped-up efforts to quash Vietnam's nascent civil society, focusing, in turn, on religious organizations, lawyers, environmentalists, LGBTQ activists, independent journalists and social media influencers.\n\nThe Politburo issued Directive 24 in July 2023, which was a clarion call against \"peaceful evolution\" and the threat posed by \"colored revolutions\", which the document warned, could be fomented by international donors, foreign investors, and students studying overseas.\n\nPolitburo language became increasingly Chinese in tone, as were the tactics employed to defend the party's monopoly of power.\n\nLike Xi and his predecessors in Beijing, Trong viewed corruption as the party's greatest vulnerability.\n\nHe launched the \"Blazing Furnace\" anti-corruption campaign, moving the anti-corruption commission from state to party control, in 2013 with himself as chairman.\n\nTrong took down a slew of rivals within the 12th Politburo, including Dinh La Thang and Hoang Trung Hai, the party chiefs of Ho Chi Minh City and Hanoi, respectively.\n\nBut the \"Blazing Furnace\" campaign spiraled out of control as it allowed then minister of public security, To Lam, to weaponize anti-corruption investigations to eliminate political rivals on the Politburo.\n\nBetween December 2022 and June 2024, seven of the 18 members of the 13th Politburo were forced to resign - a period of unprecedented political turmoil.\n\nTrong proved impotent as Lam, now serving as acting general secretary and president, removed his proteges - including President Vo Van Thuong and his assumed heir apparent National Assembly Chairman Vuong Dinh Hue - in the security chief's maneuvers to grab the top job.\n\nRELATED STORIES\n\nVietnam's Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong has died: state media\n\nMeet To Lam, Vietnam's Communist Party chief and successor to Nguyen Phu Trong\n\nTo Lam takes office as Vietnam's president\n\nVietnam's Communist Party might not attain the normalcy it seeks after reshuffle\n\nLam's ambitions created resentment\n\nTrong could only watch helplessly as Lam installed his Ministry of Security deputies, Luong Tam Quang and Nguyen Duy Ngoc, as his successor as the Minister of Public Security and the head of the Central Committee Office, respectively.\n\nAnd as Trong's health weakened, he routinely missed key meetings, with Lam - now president - standing in for him.\n\nIronically, the party apparatus emerged not just weaker and less collegial as a result of the anti-corruption campaign, but also became delegitimized in the eyes of the public as it exposed the sweeping extent of corruption among the senior leadership. Trong never took any responsibility for the damage he caused, and even seemed oblivious to it.\n\nTo be fair, Trong lived quite modestly and his children never involved themselves in business or profited from his position, a seeming birthright for the children of other top Hanoi leaders.\n\nUnder Communist Party rules, Luong Cuong, the head of the Secretariat, is supposed to stand in, but the Central Committee and Politburo announced that Lam will serve concurrently as president and acting general secretary.\n\nThat suggests that the Central Committee has determined that Lam will be elected to a full term at the 14th Congress in early 2026, though, at 67 now, would require an age waiver.\n\nPlanning for the congress is already underway. Having installed allies in key positions and having purged most rivals, Lam is in a very strong position.\n\nHowever, we have to consider the possibility that the Central Committee, which is much more powerful and independent than in China, could decide to elect a vastly new Politburo and a different general secretary.\n\nNot everyone on the Central Committee has been happy with the political instability caused by Lam's ambitious ascent, and party history offers the precedent of Le Kha Phieu, a hardline leader who was removed from office four years into his five-year term in 2001 amid public infighting that tripped up the economy.\n\nZachary Abuza is a professor at the National War College in Washington and an adjunct at Georgetown University. The views expressed here are his own and do not reflect the position of the U.S. Department of Defense, the National War College, Georgetown University or Radio Free Asia.", "source": {"uri": "rfa.org", "dataType": "news", "title": "Radio Free Asia"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/General_Secretary_of_the_Chinese_Communist_Party", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/T\u00f4_L\u00e2m", "type": "person", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "T\u00f4 "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Politburo"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Ideology", "type": "wiki", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Ideology"}}, {"uri": "country", "label": {"eng": "Vietnam"}}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Socialist_Unity_Party_of_Germany", "type": "org", "score": 4, "label": {"eng": "Socialist Unity Party of Germany"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Anti-corruption_campaign_under_Xi_Jinping", "type": "wiki", "score": 3, "label": {"eng": "Anti-corruption campaign under Xi Jinping"}}, {"uri": He was 80.\n\nFor months Trong had appeared frail at public events or missed them outright and on Thursday his duties as party chief were taken over by President To Lam. He died \"due to old age and serious illness\", the ruling Communist Party said on Friday (Jul 19).\n\nTrong became the Communist Party's general secretary in 2011, a position that in one-party authoritarian Vietnam gave him the key levers of power. He also served as Vietnam's president from 2018 to 2020.\n\nHe cultivated an image of moderation but from 2017 unleashed what many saw as a China-style crackdown on corruption, known as \"blazing furnace\" that in the past year has had a chilling effect on the economy and at times paralysed public administration.\n\nIn foreign policy, Trong advocated having \"more friends, fewer foes\" while being as flexible as bamboo.\n\nThat stance culminated in a visit by President Joe Biden to Hanoi last September that saw Vietnam lift the United States to its highest diplomatic status alongside "news", "sim": 0.6274510025978088, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/vietnam-communist-party-chief-trong-dies-at-80-state-media-says/2181721/", "title": "Vietnam Communist Party chief Trong dies at 80, state media says", "body": "It said he died \"due to old age and serious illness\", without elaborating.\n\nVietnam's President To Lam took over Trong's duties on Thursday when the party announced aging leader needed to focus on medical treatment.\n\nThough Vietnam officially has no paramount ruler, the Soviet-educated Trong as party general secretary was the most powerful figure in the Communist-ruled nation and had been in the post since 2011.\n\nIn 2021 Trong secured a third term after a rule limiting holders to two terms as party boss was waived, demonstrating his strength and significant political clout in a party that has ruled Vietnam for nearly half a century.\n\nBut in recent months, he appeared fragile in public events and missed several top-level meetings.\n\nThe party will need to decide whether Lam will be acting party general secretary until the current term for the post expires after the next Congress in 2026, or whether it will elect a new candidate earlier from within its ranks.\n\nMarxist-Leninist ideologue Trong in 2017 unleashed what many see as a China-style crackdown on corruption, known as \"blazing furnace\", under which hundreds of officials were investigated for graft and many forced to quit, including cabinet ministers, a parliament chairman and two state presidents.\n\nLam, a former chief of the powerful internal security agency, was a key figure and beneficiary of that campaign and was elected president in May after his predecessor resigned amid accusations of unspecified wrongdoing.\n\n(Reporting by Phuong Nguyen and {"uri": "2024-07-427263902", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "14:26:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T14:26:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:30:15Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6117647290229797, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/vietnams-trong-longtime-leader-and-advocate-of-bamboo-diplomacy-dies/2181774/", "title": "Vietnam's Trong, longtime leader and advocate of 'bamboo diplomacy', dies", "body": "Trong became the Communist Party's general secretary in 2011, a position that in one-party authoritarian Vietnam gave him the key levers of power. He also served as Vietnam's president from 2018 to 2020.\n\nHe cultivated an image of moderation but from 2017 unleashed what many saw as a China-style crackdown on corruption, known as \"blazing furnace\" that in the past year has had a chilling effect on the economy and at times paralysed public administration.\n\nIn foreign policy, Trong advocated having \"more friends, fewer foes\" while being as flexible as bamboo.\n\nThat stance culminated in a visit by President Joe Biden to Hanoi last September that saw Vietnam lift the United States to its highest diplomatic status alongside China, Russia, India and South Korea.\n\nThree months later, ties with Beijing - a major Communist economic partner despite recurring tensions over territorial claims in the South China Sea - were further boosted when Chinese President Xi Jinping visited.\n\nVietnam also hosted Russia's President Vladimir Putin in June and elevated Japan to its highest level of diplomatic status last year.\n\nTrong's crackdown on corruption has been long and enduring - leading to arrests or forced resignations of senior officials.\n\n\"The furnace is heating up, even fresh firewood can be burnt,\" Trong said months after he launched his signature policy.\n\nCritics lambasted the clampdown as politically motivated and rights groups also accused Trong of presiding over an intensified muzzling of dissent that has seen activists, journalists and users of social media imprisoned.\n\nBut he failed to uproot graft.\n\nIn late 2022, the country was shaken by its biggest financial fraud to date with the arrest of real-estate tycoon Truong My Lan and a run on deposits of the bank she controlled. Vietnam's central bank has had to embark on a massive rescue to avoid wider panic, costing more than $24 billion.\n\nTrong's crackdown led to the dismissal of two of Vietnam's presidents in about a year, the last one in March - developments that unnerved foreign investors who worried the anti-graft campaign had gotten out of hand.\n\nHAMMER AND SICKLE\n\nTrong's rule solidified in his second five-year term and despite his health issues, he secured a rare third term in 2021, with the party waiving a rule restricting the party chief position to two terms.\n\nAll in all, he held the party chief position for 13 years, second only to Le Duan, who ruled with an iron fist for 26 years after the death of Vietnam's founding revolutionary Ho Chi Minh.\n\nVietnam continued to flourish under Trong, benefiting from the 1986 \"Doi Moi\" reforms that transformed it from a war-torn agrarian nation into one of Asia's fastest-growing economies.\n\nVietnam's annual GDP growth averaged 5.8% over the last decade and managed decent growth even during the coronavirus pandemic that crushed economies elsewhere.\n\nBorn and raised in the suburbs of Hanoi to a farmer couple, Trong was interested in folk literature from a young age, according to a biography. He majored in philology - the study of language and historical texts - at university and one of his first published works was a 1967 review of folk poetry.\n\nStudying for two years in the Soviet Union, he went on to gain a PhD in political science, writing his thesis on the Vietnam Communist Party's efforts to strengthen its connection with the masses. In 1991, he became editor-in-chief of the party's Communist Review magazine.\n\nTrong's image was that of a man who detested excess, lived in modest state-appointed housing and refused expensive Lunar New Year gifts from friends.\n\nTwo books - each some 600 pages long and published by the party in 2019 and 2021 respectively, extolled Trong's virtues - efforts that some critics likened to an attempt at building a cult of personality.\n\nA poem in the first book describes Trong as \"a noble man, sent by the spirits to purify the system,\" an apparent reference to the corruption crackdown. \"Hammer and sickle in hand, he dispels gloom, waiting for the sunshine,\" it said.\n\nTrong was married with a son and a daughter. His children, unlike those of other high-ranking officials, are normal public servants, government officials have said.\n\n(Reporting by Phuong Nguyen, Francesco Guarascio, Khanh Vu and James Pearson; {"uri": "8233483370", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "12:18:04", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T12:18:04Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T12:17:35Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6078431606292725, "url": "https://www.manilatimes.net/2024/07/19/world/asia-oceania/vietnams-most-powerful-communist-party-leader-dies/1958502", "title": "Vietnam's most powerful Communist Party leader dies", "body": "HANOI, Vietnam -- Nguyen Phu Trong, Vietnam's most powerful contemporary leader and architect of the country's largest anti-corruption campaign, died Friday at the age of 80, state media said.\n\nDuring Trong's 13 years as general secretary of the Communist Party, thousands of people were arrested on corruption charges and a crackdown on dissidents and activists intensified in the one-party state.\n\nTrong was president from 2018-21 and served three consecutive terms as general secretary, the first to do so since the \"doi moi\" era of economic reform began in 1986.\n\nThe unprecedented feat made him the most powerful leader in decades.\n\nTrong's high-profile anti-corruption drive, which analysts say was also linked to political in-fighting, swept through the party, police, armed forces and business.\n\nGet the latest news\n\ndelivered to your inbox Sign up for The Manila Times newsletters By signing up with an email address, I acknowledge that I have read and agree to the Terms of Service and Privacy Policy.\n\nMore than 3,500 people have been indicted since 2021, official figures show, while those sent to prison include a former health minister and two previous mayors of Hanoi.\n\nFollowing a scandal related to the Covid-19 pandemic last year, President Nguyen Xuan Phuc resigned and two deputy prime ministers were removed from their positions.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nMany other prominent officials working across a wide range of sectors, from environment and energy to healthcare and banking, are under investigation.\n\nTrong would like to be remembered \"as a populist, someone very close to the people, who listens to the people,\" said Linh Nguyen, lead analyst for Control Risks on Vietnam.\n\nBut the campaign has had unintended consequences. With many fearful of being caught in its crosshairs, everyday transactions within business and the state apparatus have slowed.\n\nAccording to Linh, \"the campaign is enervating the economy, something that we can clearly see in economic growth over the past two to three years\".\n\nAdvertisement\n\nVietnam's economy grew by around five percent in 2023, falling short of a government target of 6.50 percent.\n\nUnder Trong, rights groups say a crackdown on dissent has also been escalating since 2016, with the government largely succeeding in crushing opposition.\n\nVietnam currently holds more than 160 people in prison for peacefully exercising their basic civil and political rights, according to Human Rights Watch.\n\nThe courts convicted at least 28 rights campaigners and sentenced them to long prison terms during the first 10 months of 2023, the group said.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nInternational relations\n\nBorn in April 1944 into a farming family in the Hanoi suburbs, Trong studied literature and socialist theory before traveling to the Soviet Union to complete a doctorate degree in Communist Party building.\n\nHe began his career with a low-paid editing job at a magazine specializing in communist theory in Hanoi, before working his way up to editor-in-chief.\n\nIn 1994, he became a member of the party central committee -- his first nationally prominent political role -- and he was also head of the rubber-stamp national assembly before beginning his first term as party general secretary in 2011.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nHe stood out among Vietnam's top-ranking officials as a highly educated man.\n\nTrong oversaw the strengthening of the country's relationship with several international powers during his terms in office.\n\nIn 2023, US President Joe Biden paid a brief visit to Vietnam where the two former enemies announced upgrading bilateral ties to the highest level.\n\nTrong visited the United States in 2015 and made three trips to China. Most recently, in December 2023, Chinese President Xi Jinping came to Hanoi, where the two pledged to deepen ties.\n\nAdvertisement\n\nVietnam has also become a crucial part of the supply chain for some of the world's most important companies over the past decade.\n\nBut many of them will be hoping a change in leadership means a halt to the anti-corruption campaign, said Linh, who told AFP that some complain of being badly affected by the disruption to business.\n\nHe said they will be thinking \"maybe after all the new figures and the top leadership settles down, we can go back and do business and keep investing in the country.\"", "source": {"uri": "manilatimes.net", "dataType": "news", "title": "The Manila times"}, "authors": [{"uri": "agence_france_presse@manilatimes.net", "label": {"eng": "General Secretary of the Chinese Communist Party"}}, {"uri": "http://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hanoi", "type": "loc", "score": 5, "label": {"eng": "Hanoi"}, "location": {"type": "place", {"uri": "8233919512", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "17:26:12", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T17:26:12Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T17:25:43Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://vietnamnet.vn/en/party-chief-nguyen-phu-trong-devoted-leader-of-nation-and-people-2303833.html", "title": "General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong: Devoted leader of nation and people", "body": "General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong is a great intellect and a major talent of the Vietnamese revolution. He is a thinker, a cultural advocate, and the theoretical leader of the Party. As an outstanding disciple who continually studies and follows the ideology, ethics, and style of the great President Ho Chi Minh, he has devoted his entire life to the revolutionary cause of the Party and our nation, living his life entirely for the country and the people.\n\nWith over 55 years of continuous revolutionary activity, honed through practical experience, strategic vision, and sharp thinking closely connected with practical summaries, Comrade Nguyen Phu Trong, together with the Party Central Committee, has creatively applied and developed Marxism-Leninism and Ho Chi Minh's ideology. He has continuously strengthened the Party, making it increasingly clean and strong, built a socialist rule-of-law state of the people, by the people, and for the people, and supplemented, perfected, and led the successful implementation of the renewal policy, bringing our country to a level of prosperity, potential, reputation, and international standing never seen before.\n\nThroughout his revolutionary career, Party work and Party building held a particularly important position for Comrade Nguyen Phu Trong. Applying Ho Chi Minh's ideology on Party building creatively, Comrade Nguyen Phu Trong delved deeply into clarifying the essence of the Party, the role of the Party in the country's renewal process, and the construction of a ruling Party based on Vietnam's renewal practices. From this foundation, he, along with the Central Committee, formulated and successfully led the implementation of strategic policies on Party building and rectification; resolutely and persistently fighting against individualism, degradation, and corruption within the Party, while continuously fostering revolutionary ethics, intellect, and pioneering spirit. This effort has also emphasized maintaining good traditions and a close relationship with the people. Under the Party's leadership, headed by General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong, our Party has demonstrated courage and wisdom, leading the entire Party, people, and military to achieve significant successes in the national renewal process, thwarting all hostile schemes, and building a society that is truly \"ethical and civilized.\"\n\nAs Chairman of the National Assembly and General Secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam, Comrade Nguyen Phu Trong was deeply committed to building a socialist rule of law state for the people, by the people. Under the leadership of Comrade Nguyen Phu Trong, our Party for the first time issued a Resolution on continuing to build and perfect the socialist rule-of-law State of Vietnam in the new period. This Resolution aims to \"Perfect the socialist rule-of-law State of Vietnam, of the people, by the people, for the people, led by the Communist Party of Vietnam; with a complete legal system, strictly and consistently enforced; uphold the Constitution and the law, respect, ensure, and effectively protect human rights and citizen rights; unified state power, clearly assigned, closely coordinated, effectively controlled; professional, lawful, modern administration and judiciary; streamlined, clean, effective, and efficient state apparatus; a cadre of officials, civil servants, and public employees with sufficient qualities, capacities, truly professional, and upright; modern, effective national governance; meeting the requirements of rapid and sustainable national development, becoming a developed, high-income country oriented towards socialism by 2045.\" (1).\n\nImbued with Ho Chi Minh's ideology and deeply aware of the crucial role of culture, \"Culture is the soul of the nation,\" \"If culture remains, the nation remains,\" cultural advocate Nguyen Phu Trong, an outstanding leader on the Party's cultural front, has dedicated significant effort to building an advanced culture imbued with national identity. This culture truly serves as the spiritual foundation of society, an intrinsic strength, and an important driving force for national development. Under the leadership of comrade Nguyen Phu Trong, the 13th Party Congress documents comprehensively and profoundly addressed the cultural field. The National Conference on Culture, held after more than 70 years, marked a milestone in aligning the thoughts and actions of the entire Party, people, and military to strongly promote the role of culture in the cause of building and defending the Fatherland, realizing the aspiration for a prosperous and happy nation.\n\nWith deep political insight and strategic thinking, Comrade Nguyen Phu Trong, along with the Party Central Committee, has advanced Vietnam's foreign policy thinking, summarized practical experiences, and developed the art of \"Bamboo Diplomacy.\" This has built and developed a distinctive Vietnamese diplomacy characterized by the \"Vietnamese bamboo\" identity. Under the Party's leadership, directly guided by General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong, the essence of \"Bamboo Diplomacy\" has been strongly promoted, creating historic turning points and qualitative changes in Vietnam's relations with major partners. Never before has Vietnam's position, reputation, and image as a reliable partner, an active and responsible member on the international stage been as prominent as it is today. Vietnam has also never integrated as deeply and extensively into the global economy, international politics, and human civilization as it does now.\n\nDuring his tenure as President, Chairman of the National Defense and Security Council, and Commander-in-Chief of the People's Armed Forces, Comrade Nguyen Phu Trong paid close attention to the People's Army and the People's Public Security forces. He focused on building a strong, cohesive, and unified military and police force. He frequently reminded the armed forces to internalize, learn from, and follow Ho Chi Minh's ideology, ethics, and style, emphasizing that \"Honor is the most sacred and noble thing.\" He encouraged them to wholeheartedly serve the Fatherland and the people, to \"rely on the people to work,\" and to \"be truly loyal, respectful, and loving to the people,\" maintaining a close bond with the people, protecting their interests, and enhancing their trust and support.\n\nUnder the Party's leadership, directly guided by General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong, significant achievements have been made in building a lean, strong, and clean armed force that meets the demands and tasks of the new situation. The police and military forces have remained united and coordinated closely, acting as both the sword and shield, and the two wings of a bird, to protect and maintain peace and stability for the country's development.\n\nCentral to the ideology of Comrade Nguyen Phu Trong is the focus on the people, humanity, and a wholehearted commitment to serving them, with the people being the core and center of the renovation process. Regarding the Party, he affirmed, \"Our Party must bear the highest responsibility to the people, taking care of their material and spiritual lives\"(2). He stated, \"If the Party's line does not reflect the interests of the people, the country, and the nation, and does not conform to the evolutionary laws of history, it is a wrong line\"(3), and \"Maintaining close ties with the people is the rule of existence, development, and activity of the Party, and it is the decisive factor that creates the Party's strength\"(4).\n\nWhen analyzing the differences between a socialist rule-of-law state and a capitalist rule-of-law state, he clarified, \"The essence of a socialist rule-of-law state differs from a bourgeois rule-of-law state in that: under capitalism, rule of law essentially serves to protect and serve the interests of the bourgeoisie, whereas, under socialism, rule of law serves to express and realize the people's mastery, ensuring and protecting the interests of the vast majority of the people\"(5).\n\nRegarding the socialist-oriented market economy, he summarized, \"A fundamental characteristic and an important attribute of the socialist orientation in our market economy is to link the economy with society, to unify economic policy with social policy, to achieve economic growth alongside social progress and fairness at every step, in every policy, and throughout the development process\"(6). He emphasized that \"every economic policy must aim at social development..., encouraging lawful enrichment alongside poverty alleviation, caring for those who have contributed to the country, and supporting those who are unfortunate or in difficult circumstances.\"\n\nUnder the leadership of Comrade Nguyen Phu Trong, our Party has issued resolutions on socio-economic development and ensuring national defense and security across six economic regions nationwide until 2030, with a vision to 2045. These resolutions set goals, visions, directions, and solutions to create strong, breakthrough developments, contributing to the successful achievement of the country's goals over the next 100 years under the Party's leadership, aiming for Vietnam to become a developed country by the mid-21st century, fulfilling President Ho Chi Minh's aspiration to see our nation stand shoulder to shoulder with the great powers of the five continents.\n\nThroughout his life, General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong has tirelessly dedicated himself to the revolutionary cause of the Party and our nation with a spirit and steely determination, never retreating in the face of obstacles and difficulties. He has affirmed a great character, upholding \"Honor as the most sacred and noble thing,\" maintaining principles, and living his life fully for the country and the people.\n\nComrade Nguyen Phu Trong is truly an exemplary and model figure of pure revolutionary ethics, \"public-spirited and selfless,\" with a simple lifestyle, democratic, dedicated, and scientific working style, respecting and loving people. He is highly respected, trusted, and loved by cadres, Party members, and the people, and is highly regarded and respected by international friends.\n\nWe are firmly confident that, under the leadership of the Party, by steadfastly applying and creatively developing Marxism-Leninism, Ho Chi Minh's ideology, and the Party's theoretical line of innovation; by steadfastly maintaining national independence and socialism; and by adhering to the principles of Party building, our entire Party, people, and military will unite, work together, seize opportunities, and overcome challenges. This unity will ensure that our Party and political system are truly clean and comprehensively strong, leading to rapid and sustainable national development, firmly protecting the Fatherland. By 2030, when our Party celebrates its 100th anniversary, we aim for our country to become a developing nation with modern industry and high middle-income status. This will lay a solid foundation for achieving the goal by 2045, when we celebrate 100 years of the founding of the nation, to turn our country into a developed, high-income nation oriented towards socialism.\n\nGeneral To Lam, Politburo Member, President of the Socialist Republic of Vietnam\n\n(1) Resolution of the Sixth Plenary Session of the 13th Central Committee of the Communist Party on continuing to build and perfect the socialist rule-of-law State of Vietnam in the new period.\n\n(2) Nguyen Phu Trong: Building and Rectifying the Party - Some Theoretical and Practical Issues. National Political Publishing House, Hanoi, 2012, p. 65.\n\n(3) Nguyen Phu Trong: Building and Rectifying the Party - Some Theoretical and Practical Issues. National Political Publishing House, Hanoi, 2012, p. 66.\n\n(4) Nguyen Phu Trong: Building and Rectifying the Party - Some Theoretical and Practical Issues. {"uri": "8233639710", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "14:03:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T14:03:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T14:02:45Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.6039215922355652, "url": "https://dnyuz.com/2024/07/19/nguyen-phu-trong-vietnams-top-communist-party-leader-dead-at-80/", "title": "Nguyen Phu Trong, Vietnam's top Communist Party leader, dead at 80", "body": "Trong carried significant political influence in his party. He was educated in the Soviet Union and was regarded as a Marxist-Leninist ideologue.\n\nVietnam's ruling Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong died on Friday after holding the country's most powerful position for 13 years. He was 80.\n\nHe died in the early afternoon \"due to old age and serious illness,\" the Communist Party said in a statement on its website, without elaborating further on the nature of the illness.\n\nThe statement cited information from Trong's medical team, saying he died \"after a period of illness, despite being wholeheartedly treated by the Party, the State, a collective of professors, doctors, leading medical experts.\"\n\nBut in recent months, he appeared fragile in public events and missed several top-level meetings.\n\nTrong was educated in the Soviet Union and was regarded as a Marxist-Leninist ideologue. In 2017 he unleashed what many saw as a China-style crackdown on corruption, known as \"blazing furnace,\" under which hundreds of officials were investigated for graft and many forced to quit, including cabinet ministers, a parliament chairman and two state presidents.\n\nLam, a former chief of the powerful internal security agency, has been a key player in that campaign and was elected president in May after his predecessor resigned amid accusations of unspecified wrongdoing.", "source": {"uri": "dnyuz.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "DNyuz"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "8233433913", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:46:38", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:46:38Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:46:06Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5960784554481506, "url": "https://www.irishexaminer.com/world/arid-41439910.html", "title": "Vietnam Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong dies aged 80", "body": "Mr Trong had dominated Vietnamese politics since 2011, when he was elected party chief. During his tenure, he worked to consolidate the Communist Party's power in Vietnam's single-party political system.\n\nIn the decade before he took the top role in Vietnamese politics, the balance of power had shifted more towards the governmental wing led by then-prime minister Nguyen Tan Dung.\n\nBorn in 1944 in Hanoi, Mr Trong was a Marxist-Leninist ideologue who earned a degree in philosophy before becoming a member of the Communist Party at the age of 22. He viewed corruption as the single gravest threat in maintaining the party's legitimacy.\n\n\"A country without discipline would be chaotic and unstable,\" Mr Trong said in 2016 after being re-elected to the party's helm. Officially, Vietnam has no top leader, but the Communist Party chief is traditionally seen as the most powerful.\n\nHe launched a sweeping anti-corruption campaign known as the \"blazing furnace\" that hit both business and political elites.\n\nSince 2016, thousands of party officials have been disciplined. They included former presidents Nguyen Xuan Phuc and Vo Van Thuong and the former head of parliament, Vuong Dinh Hue. In all, eight members of the powerful Politburo were ousted on corruption allegations, compared with none between 1986 and 2016.\n\nMr Trong studied in the Soviet Union from 1981 to 1983, and there was speculation that under his leadership, Vietnam would move closer to Russia and China.\n\nHowever, the Southeast Asian nation followed a pragmatic policy of \"bamboo diplomacy\", a phrase he coined that referred to the plant's flexibility, bending but not breaking in the shifting headwinds of geopolitics.\n\nVietnam maintained its traditional ties with its much larger neighbour, China, dispute differences over sovereignty in the South China Sea. Nguyen Phu Trong. We pay our respects to the departed leader. {"uri": "2024-07-426403880", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-18", "time": "19:58:09", "dateTime": "2024-07-18T19:58:09Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-18T19:57:59Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5882353186607361, "url": "https://www.rfa.org/english/news/vietnam/to-lam-profile-07182024155004.html", "title": "To Lam: The man with the golden steak is now leading Vietnam", "body": "In the West, he may be best known for eating a gold-covered steak while his countrymen survive on an average of about US$10 a day.\n\nBut in Hanoi, Vietnam's new top leader To Lam has for years been seen as an operator whose decades in politics long paved the way for his ascent.\n\nOn Thursday, that climb reached a new zenith after Vietnamese state media announced that Lam, 67, would take over the duties for Communist Party General Secretary Nguyen Phu Trong.\n\nIt comes less than two months after Lam was elevated to the Vietnamese presidency - a move that put him in pole position for the general secretary job, the most powerful in the country.\n\nThe son of a Vietnamese police colonel, Lam began his career in public security in 1979. He joined the Communist Party of Vietnam in 1981, eventually rising to become the minister for public security - the country's top security official - in 2016.\n\nIn 2019, he was awarded the rank of general by then-president Trong.\n\nSecurity czar\n\nIn his capacity as security minister, he focused on internal politics and counter-intelligence - areas that may well have helped him to later cement his political powers.\n\nThe stint was not without controversy. In 2017, Lam was accused of being involved in the kidnapping of Trinh Xuan Thanh, a fugitive oil executive and former provincial official, in Berlin.\n\nThanh later returned to Hanoi through Slovakia. The government denied kidnapping but the case led to a temporary rift in diplomatic relations between Germany and Vietnam.\n\nBut it would fit a larger pattern of alleged transnational repression and quashing of dissent overseen by Lam.\n\nHis term as security minister saw the arrests and suspected kidnappings of journalist critics, including RFA blogger Truong Duy Nhat, who disappeared in Thailand in 2019 but is now in jail in Vietnam serving a 10-year sentence.\n\nGolden steak and 'Onion Bae'\n\nIn 2021, Lam was involved in another controversy after he was caught on video eating a piece of gold-plated steak at a luxury restaurant in London.\n\nA video clip of the general being fed a US$2,000 steak by celebrity chef Salt Bae went viral, causing a public outcry at home.\n\nThis was followed by a draconian crackdown, including the arrest and jailing of a noodle-seller nicknamed \"Onion Bae\" who had dared to ridicule Lam by posting a parody of the incident to social media. He remains in jail.\n\nLam subsequently ramped up anti-corruption crackdowns that saw off potential rivals within the party in what critics have said were clearly politically motivated investigations.\n\nLam's enthusiastic implementation of this so-called \"Burning Furnace\" campaign led to the sacking of half a dozen senior ministers and Politburo members within the span of months beginning in 2022.\n\nYet Lam and Trong, the ally he succeeds, are also said to have questionable hidden interests.\n\nIn May, the Ti\u1ebfng D\u00e2n newspaper revealed that a younger brother of To Lam, To Dung, was the chairman of the construction and real estate firm Xuan Cau Group, noting that the company had been conspicuously absent from any investigation even as it has won projects worth billions of Vietnamese dong with little oversight.\n\nPrivate man\n\nLittle else is known about the private life of Vietnam's new top man.\n\nHe does not appear to have ever given any remarks to Western media and nothing in English has been written of his immediate family, though Vietnamese reports say he has been twice married, first to Vu Hong Loan, the sister of a Vietnamese police major general and currently to Ngo Phuong Ly.\n\nHe appears to have several children. One daughter was revealed to have graduated from London's prestigious School of Oriental and Asian Studies, or SOAS, in 2023.\n\nOn the global stage, Lam has made clear his endorsement of the so-called \"Bamboo diplomacy\" Hanoi has undertaken to balance its relations between East and West.\n\nIn June, he welcomed Russian President Vladimir Putin, weeks after his swearing in as president, calling him \"comrade\" and hailing a successful visit.\n\nHanoi saw visits from Chinese President Xi Jinping and U.S. President Joe Biden within the previous nine months.\n\nWhether his caretaker role becomes a more permanent one, there seems little likelihood that Lam would veer from the established path. At his presidential swearing-in in May, he promised to \"continue to strengthen the party's capabilities, its ruling power and combat prowess.\"", "source": {"uri": "rfa.org", "dataType": "news", {"uri": "2024-07-427107664", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "12:02:02", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T12:02:02Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T07:45:00Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5803921818733215, "url": "https://www.usnews.com/news/world/articles/2024-07-19/vietnams-lam-a-public-security-maven-who-could-strengthen-his-grip-on-power", "title": "Vietnam's Lam, a Public Security Maven Who Could Strengthen His Grip on Power", "body": "HANOI (Reuters) - Vietnam's President To Lam, who has taken on the duties of deceased Communist Party chief Nguyen Phu Trong, is a skilful behind-the-scenes operator long involved in public security who is seen as capable of consolidating power further.\n\nLike China, Vietnam is ruled by a communist party but, unlike its neighbour, it has engaged in more collective decision-making with leaders being subject to multiple checks.\n\nBut if Lam, 67, were to continue to wear both the president and party chief hats, as Xi Jinping does, for some time, the Southeast Asian nation could see a more autocratic style of leadership, according to analysts, diplomats and activists.\n\nSome investors would welcome the emergence of a stronger leader who could put an end to over a year of political wrangling, they said. The wrangling has had a negative impact on investment in a country that is home to large manufacturing operations for dozens of top multinationals.\n\nEconomic and foreign policy are not expected to change substantially, but civil liberties could be further eroded, they warned.\n\n\"If Lam became the most powerful man in Vietnam without checks and balances it would be bad for Vietnam and erode the norm of democratic centralism,\" said Carl Thayer, a senior expert on Vietnam at the Australian Defence Force Academy.\n\nIt is, however, not clear how and when the party would replace Trong with an acting general secretary or a permanent one.\n\nLam could, in theory, continue in both roles until 2026 when all top jobs will be up for grabs for the next five-year term. Trong himself held the two positions for nearly three years until April 2021 after the death of a former president.\n\nBut Lam may face internal opposition that could even lead to a succession crisis, said Le Hong Hiep and Nguyen Khac Giang from the Singapore-based think tank ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute in an article published on Friday.\n\nSTELLAR RISE\n\nThe son of a senior police officer, Lam studied security and obtained a PhD in law. He went on to become the minister for public security in 2016, a four-star general and was admitted in 2021 to the Communist Party's Politburo, the most powerful body in the country.\n\nHis ascent in roughly three months this year from minister to president and now also assuming the party chief's duties only underlines his grip on power, according to experts. His election as president had been seen as a \"stepping stone\" to the party chief job, they add.\n\nLam also appears to have maintained indirect control over the powerful public security ministry, which is now led by an official who hails from Lam's native province and is seen as close to him.\n\nLam's intense focus on public security is clearly outlined in his 2021 book titled \"New Findings on National Security for the 13th Party Congress\".\n\n\"The combination of national security together with economy, culture and foreign affairs is a must in our Party's vision in order to both build and protect socialism at the same time,\" he wrote.\n\nHe has been a central figure in the fight against corruption, Trong's signature policy known as \"blazing furnace\" that has been in place since 2017 and has recently intensified.\n\nSince 2023, two of Vietnam's presidents and one chair of parliament have quit over unspecified wrongdoing, with the public security ministry playing a central role in the investigations.\n\nLam's access to intelligence and sensitive information has also meant that he is feared, with Western diplomats often lowering their voices or not naming him when referring to Lam in private meetings.\n\nLast year, a noodle vendor was sentenced to five years in prison after posting a video that was considered to be mocking Lam. In the video, the vendor imitated a celebrity chef who fed Lam a gold-encrusted steak at his London restaurant while Vietnam was under COVID-19 lockdowns in 2021.\n\n(Reporting by Francesco Guarascio and Phuong Nguyen; Editing by Edwina Gibbs)", "source": {"uri": "usnews.com", "dataType": "news", "title": "U.S. News & World Report"}, "authors": [], "concepts": [{"uri": {"uri": "2024-07-427263893", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "14:26:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T14:26:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T12:16:26Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://theprint.in/world/vietnams-top-leader-trong-dies-at-80-party-says/2181868/", "title": "Vietnam's top leader Trong dies at 80, party says", "body": "The statement cited information from Trong's medical team, saying he died \"after a period of illness, despite being wholeheartedly treated by the Party, the State, a collective of professors, doctors, leading medical experts\".\n\nThe country's president, To Lam, had taken over Trong's duties on Thursday when the party announced the ageing leader needed to focus on medical treatment.\n\nThe party will need to decide whether Lam will continue as acting party general secretary until the current term for the post expires after the next Congress in 2026, or whether it will elect a new candidate before then from within its ranks.\n\nAlthough Vietnam officially has no paramount ruler, Trong was the country's most powerful figure as party general secretary and had been in the post since 2011.\n\nHe secured a third term in 2021 after a rule limiting holders to two terms as party boss was waived, demonstrating his strength and significant political clout in a party that has ruled Vietnam for nearly half a century.\n\nBut in recent months, he appeared fragile in public events and missed several top-level meetings.\n\nTrong was educated in the Soviet Union and was regarded as a Marxist-Leninist ideologue. In 2017 he unleashed what many saw as a China-style crackdown on corruption, known as \"blazing furnace\", under which hundreds of officials were investigated for graft and many forced to quit, including cabinet ministers, a parliament chairman and two state presidents.\n\nLam, a former chief of the powerful internal security agency, has been a key player in that campaign and was elected president in May after his predecessor resigned amid accusations of unspecified wrongdoing.\n\n(Reporting by Phuong Nguyen and Francesco Guarascio; Editing by Martin Petty and Frances Kerry)", {"uri": "8233767494", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "15:30:10", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T15:30:10Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T15:29:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5686274766921997, "url": "https://www.scmp.com/news/china/diplomacy/article/3271206/communist-party-china-sends-vietnam-condolences-death-leader-nguyen-phu-trong", "title": "Communist Party of China sends Vietnam condolences on death of Nguyen Phu Trong", "body": "The Communist Party of Vietnam general secretary, who maintained the friendship between the two nations and parties, died at 80 due to serious illness, Vietnam says\n\nThe Communist Party of China has sent a message of condolence to its Vietnamese counterpart for the death of its chief Nguyen Phu Trong, state media reported on Friday.\n\nTrong, general secretary of the Communist Party of Vietnam since 2011, died Friday afternoon at the age of 80, \u201cdue to old age and serious illness\u201d, according to Vietnam\u2019s official announcement.\n\nIn the condolence message, the Central Committee of the Chinese party, its highest decision-making unit, praised Trong as \u201ca good comrade, good brother and good friend\u201d, and a \u201cclose comrade and sincere friend of the Communist Party of China and the Chinese people\u201d.\n\n\u201cHe inherited and developed the traditional friendship of \u2018comrades and brothers\u2019 between the two parties and two nations and forged a deep friendship with the Communist Party of China and Chinese leaders,\u201d the message reads, referring to Trong\u2019s joint effort with Xi Jinping, China\u2019s president and general secretary of the Chinese Communist Party, to elevate those ties to a \u201ccommunity of shared destiny with strategic significance\u201d last year.\n\n\u201cChina has always regarded Vietnam as a priority in its neighbourhood diplomacy and is willing to work with Vietnam to continuously consolidate political mutual trust, strengthen solidarity and cooperation, and push forward the building of a China-Vietnam community with a shared destiny in a deeper and more practical way, so as to benefit the two peoples and contribute to peace and development in the region and the world,\u201d it said.\n\nThe state Vietnam News Agency announced on Thursday that Trong had handed duties over to President To Lam, who took office on May 22, to focus on his medical treatment. At the same time, the Vietnamese government awarded him a Gold Star medal, the country\u2019s highest honour.\n\nTrong was one of Vietnam\u2019s most powerful leaders in decades. His death came amid political turmoil since March, which has seen three of its top five leaders step down in an anti-corruption campaign.\n\nDuring his tenure Trong developed a close relationship with the Chinese government, though the two nations still have unresolved disputes in the South China Sea, which occasionally grow into stand-offs.\n\nChina is Vietnam\u2019s largest trading partner and a major foreign investor. And Vietnam in recent years has become a leading destination for supply chain and manufacturing companies relocate from China against the backdrop of US-China trade tensions and geopolitical rivalry.\n\nUnder Trong\u2019s leadership, Vietnam also advanced ties with the United States and its allies, while maintaining relations with Russia and North Korea.", "source": {"uri": "scmp.com", {"uri": "8233525243", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "12:47:03", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T12:47:03Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T12:45:41Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5647059082984924, "url": "https://www.dailymail.co.uk/wires/afp/article-13651491/To-Lam-ex-public-security-minister-turned-Vietnam-leader.html", "title": "To Lam: ex-public security minister turned Vietnam top leader", "body": "To Lam, named Vietnam's interim party leader this week, is a powerful former public security minister who has been swiftly elevated by a corruption crackdown that swept away other contenders\n\nTo Lam, named Vietnam's interim party leader this week, is a powerful former public security minister who has been swiftly elevated by a corruption crackdown that swept away other contenders.\n\nOn Thursday, he was handed the reins of power after the Communist Party announced its chief Nguyen Phu Trong would be focusing on \"active treatment\" for an undisclosed condition.\n\nOn Friday evening, the party announced Trong had died at a military hospital.\n\nLam, 67, has been jockeying for influence for some time, according to analysts, with Trong's mandate officially up in 2026.\n\nIn May, Lam became president -- a largely ceremonial role -- after his predecessor resigned as part of a vast anti-graft purge.\n\nThousands of people -- including top officials and senior business leaders -- have been caught up in the Southeast Asian country's \"blazing furnace\" crackdown on graft.\n\nLam's elevation comes as little surprise to analysts, and if he eventually formally succeeds Trong, he is not expected to vastly shift the country's existing policies.\n\nBut it marks a \"total victory\" for Lam, said Benoit de Treglode, research director at the Institute for Strategic Research at France's military academy in Paris.\n\n\"He is an extremely strong statesman, supported by a ministry at the heart of the Vietnamese political project,\" he said, adding that Lam's interim leadership could last until the party congress in January 2026.\n\n\"We will witness a personalisation of power around him, which will lead to political stability\" and a movement towards \"continuity, and not rupture.\"\n\nVietnam's leadership structure gives the party's secretary general most power, with the president occupying a largely ceremonial role that includes meeting foreign counterparts. The leadership also includes the prime minister and the head of the National Assembly.\n\nThe country's politburo is central to steering policy and Trong's departure is unlikely to mark a break with existing domestic and foreign priorities.\n\n\"Major changes to Vietnam's economic and foreign policy should not be expected,\" wrote Le Hong Hiep and Nguyen Khac Giang, analysts at the ISEAS-Yusof Ishak Institute think tank.\n\n\"Ultimately, preserving the Party's rule will be the new leader's main priority, much like it was for Trong,\" they wrote in an analysis Friday.\n\n- 'Last man standing' -\n\nLam was born in 1957 in Hung Yen, then part of communist North Vietnam, and entered the ministry of public security after graduating from the police academy.\n\nHe has spent his whole career within the secretive ministry, which deals with the monitoring of dissent and surveillance of activists in the authoritarian state.\n\nRights groups say the government has in recent years stepped up a crackdown on civil society groups.\n\nHe is also deputy head of the steering committee on anti-corruption, and has used the anti-graft drive to outmanoeuvre his rivals for power, according to Zachary Abuza, a professor at the National War College in Washington.\n\nHe weaponised anti-corruption investigations to \"systematically take down rivals in the politburo who were eligible to become general secretary,\" he told AFP earlier this year.\n\nOther than Prime Minister Pham Minh Chinh, \"that leaves To Lam as the last man standing\".\n\nLam's allies have moved into key positions, including as his replacement at the head of the police.\n\nThe anti-corruption drive has proved popular with the public.\n\nBut analysts warn the turmoil may threaten the country's reputation for stability, which has helped it build a highly successful export-driven manufacturing economy, making products for major global brands.\n\nLam's elevation creates uncertainty for the country's beleaguered activists.\n\n\"He has proved to be repressive towards the democratic movement,\" dissident journalist Le Anh Hung told AFP.\n\n\"We only have hopes at the moment. Time will tell.\"\n\nLam's ascension has hit only one major road bump, in 2021, when a video surfaced of him enjoying a bite of steak smothered in gold leaf at a London restaurant, shortly after laying a wreath at the grave of Karl Marx.\n\nA noodle seller and former activist who had parodied the chef behind the pricey meal was later imprisoned.", "source": {"uri": "dailymail.co.uk", {"uri": "8233401322", "lang": "eng", "isDuplicate": false, "date": "2024-07-19", "time": "11:25:40", "dateTime": "2024-07-19T11:25:40Z", "dateTimePub": "2024-07-19T11:24:56Z", "dataType": "news", "sim": 0.5568627715110779, "url": "https://www.bbc.com/news/articles/c51y3r09zr2o", "title": "Nguyen Phu Trong: Vietnam's long-serving leader dies at 80", "body": "Besides overseeing the supercharged growth of Vietnam's economy, the 80-year-old was known for his \"blazing furnaces\" anti-corruption campaign.\n\nMr Trong's death comes at a time of political turbulence for Vietnam's Communist leadership. In recent months three top leaders quit following unspecified accusations of wrongdoing.\n\nAccording to an official statement released on Friday, Mr Trong died \"due to old age and serious illness\".\n\nIt comes a day after the Vietnamese government said in a surprise announcement that Mr Trong needed time to \"focus on active treatment\" for an unspecified medical condition. It added that the president would take over Mr Trong's duties in running the party's central committee, politburo and secretariat.\n\nOn that same day, the government also awarded Mr Trong the Gold Star, the highest honour given in Vietnam, for contributions to the party and country.\n\nMr Trong was seen as recently as late June, when he welcomed Russian President Vladimir Putin on a state visit.\n\nBut after that he failed to attend several events, including the official launch of a book compiling some of his speeches.\n\nIn recent years, there were several instances where he would disappear from the public eye for long stretches of time. In 2019, he was reported to have had a stroke.\n\nLittle would be said about these absences by the state, though Mr Trong occasionally acknowledged he had health and ageing issues. Observers say the state's discretion over the health of party leaders and government officials is one way of portraying Vietnam as a stable nation under single-party rule.\n\nIn 2018, the country passed a law classifying top officials' health as a state secret, prompting the already tightly-controlled local media to be even more cautious. Intense speculation over his health has long thrived on social media.\n\nObservers say he leaves behind a deep but incomplete legacy. After rising to power in 2011 he stayed on as general secretary for a rare three terms. During this period he also acted as president from 2018 to 2021.\n\nHe saw the need to open up Vietnam's economy - under his watch, the country's GDP per capita more than doubled and Vietnam inked a series of free trade agreements with the West and Asian neighbours. As Vietnam's top security official, Lam had led the anti-graft campaign until becoming president in May, when his predecessor resigned after being caught up in it.\n\nThe party's Politburo asked Lam to \"preside over the work of the Party Central Committee, the Politburo, and the Secretariat,\" according to a statement from its central office which was the first official confirmation of Trong's poor health.\n\nRumors about his health have swirled in Vietnamese politics since he was first hospitalized in 2019, and more recently when he appeared extremely frail while meeting visiting Russian President Vladmir Putin.\n\nTrong' death leaves behind a yawning political vacuum in Vietnam. Although Lam is widely viewed as the likely next party chief, Giang predicted \"a very uncertain time\" in Vietnamese politics because the norms and institutions governing the country are \"very shaky.\"\n\n\"Now it isn't only about the rules or norms, but it is also about who holds the most power,\" Giang said.\n\nThe central committee of the Chinese Communist Party sent its condolences to
